SS0Q4amzIm0AJY0PMnb98g.text: A well done restaurant and something different than the traditional faire.  First the bar, spectacular when it's warm out, great cocktails and enjoyable happy hour.  I find their wines by the glass robe a step above most Pittsburgh joints.  On to dinner, the wine list is good but more over- priced than it should be. Cautious for the classic wine list bait and switch, "oh sorry out of the '08 but we have the '09." which is aggravating considering how much they pump their wine room.  The food though was fantastic.  Seared foie gras was excellent paired with a chocolate bread which was a touch unbalanced but good flavor profile. The lamb was superb joined with roasted garlic and polenta with a cherry tomato aus jus.  The dessert was a lemon poppy seed cake with sorbet which for a dessert lover that shines away from overly sweet this was very refreshing.  The ice wine was good but a rip-off.  Overall a very elegant meal and a good change of pace from the normal Pittsburgh restaurants we frequent.

YS9zWF3bjAwwwE4YYljOug.text: Tried the Candy Bar and the Warm Dark Chocolate Cake.  The deserts were incredible.  The staff was extremely friendly and knowledgable about the menu!

DZJEoRAJyHe1WzJs64gTBA.text: My friends and I dined at Eleven last night before going to see a show at the Benedum. Everything about our experience was great. The food was very very good. I started with the baby kale Caesar salad and had the grilled swordfish as my entree. The grilled swordfish was fantastic. Others entrees at the table were the salmon, pork chop and strozzapreti. Everyone enjoyed their meals. Our waiter was great too. He was extremely friendly and very helpful when it came to our questions about the menu. I would definitely recommend Eleven and planned on returning. Would love to try their brunch next time.

pxCHcKau6ODOVEwldw-cyQ.text: Great food and very good service! The baby kale salad is soft and tender with a yummy ceasar dressing amd the rib eye was veryyy good! I would come back anytime when im in the Pittsburgh area!

MddeuItXtcsgsHxRc91-Lg.text: Just want to add, I came back here for brunch and it somehow exceeded the amazing dinner I had here earlier.  Don't miss the bloody maria, a fiery spicy way to kick off your morning!

CdRSfFW5s-_lYpph5HhrSg.text: Pure decadence! I've been to plenty of places I'd consider to be upscale, but I've never had five servers waiting on my every whim. There was a server for bread service, two for delivering entrees, and someone entirely separate took our order. The cocktails my date and I ordered were top-notch. Splurge and order the barrel-aged Manhattan; they take already delicious Maker's Mark and age it even further in oak barrels. The presentation on the entrees was gorgeous; my carrots and brussels must have been meticulously placed in an artful arrangement on the plate. The food itself was incredibly tasty, though I felt my pork was maybe sliiightly overcooked for my taste. My date's steak tenderloin, however, was probably the best I've ever had. I felt everything was well priced for the level of service and quality of ingredients. If I'm ever in Pittsburgh, this will be a repeat stop because I'm afraid I won't get such a great experience anywhere else.

-Ue_jOXDDzuD03IM1UBgrw.text: Wish I could just base this review on their food, but the waitress I had was so horrible that I can't provide a better review.  I kindly asked for sparking water as she was pouring tap, but when I did the waitress gave me the dirtiest look, grabbed the water glass, and took off without saying a word.  Didn't see her for the next 10-15 minutes.

mHsdeoyAxMbDTpoOwFhnaQ.text: I ate at Eleven twice on my most recent trip to Pittsburgh.  The first time - I tried the butternut squash bisque and the scallops - both were very good.  It was what I needed after OD'ing on carbs at Primanti's. On my second trip, I went with the lamb taco - normally I am not a fan of lamb - but the fact that it was pulled/shredded intrigued me.  So glad I got it because that has to be one of the best most unique dishes I have had in a awhile.  I love that the ingredients they list are easy to identify - lamb, goat cheese, tomatillo sauce - those flavors work well together.  The shell did not wrap around the taco - it was more on the bottom so I used a fork and knife to eat the taco.  I was craving another one but instead I decided to try dessert. I asked the bartender for some recommendations and ended up getting the tangerine pudding cake - it was platted with a light blackberry sauce and toasted macamedias and had shaved ice cream on top - yummers!  I never would have imagined that coming together - but it was delicious.  The tangerine was sweet and mild - the blackberry was slightly more dominant in flavor.  The pudding cake had a flan like bottom and the shaved ice cream on top made it chill. Eleven has a killer happy hour - 4-6pm which offers a solid selection of wines, mixed drinks, and appies at very reasonable prices. A Super Tuscan at $6 at the end of a work day makes for the start of a very happy evening. The offering of starters, a tavern menu, a fine dining, and tasting menu - makes this place appealling for all sorts of occassions.   I also like that they have valet for $5 - I was driving around earlier and it seems like so many places did not have valet and were charging $10-$15 in downtown for evening parking. The only thing I was not crazy about are the bar chairs - I felt like I was eating at a distance from the bar.

76SaElGK7xnSIrBjieTidQ.text: We came here for brunch on Sunday and had the prix fix menu of an appetizer, entree and drink for $25. Normally we don't eat so much but we decided to indulge. That wasn't the best idea. Keep in mind that the portions are a decent size (not huge, but not small either like I had expected) and the food is luxurious. We would have been good with one appetizer and one entree between the two of us. But anyway.  Eleven is beautiful decorated and sticks to the motif of trendy and intimate, which seemed pretty tough to do because of how large the place is. We were seated on the upper level and felt comfortable secluded and never noticed the rest of the patrons. Our waiter was professional, courteous and attentive without being annoying. He also suggested some vegetarian favorites and dishes we could modify. Our food was delicious and even better as leftovers because the flavors had time to kick in. My favorite part of brunch (aside from being with my boo)? The drink I ordered. The First Snowfall was light, refreshing, slightly sweet and it really felt like I was drinking delicate, little snowflakes. It made me really happy.

yhlr5jJrHK1kP9hOU6aR3g.text: I loved the prefix brunch here. Great food, drinks and atmosphere, even the complementary baked goods basket was really good. We had oyster, smoked salmon as appetizer and steak and egg, lamb as entrees. All of them tasted really good.

NpPT8xKgojQvEWcFIjyjgw.text: Beautiful and elegant, Sorry to see the much mentioned lamb not on the menu. Loved the Prime lion steak perfectly cooked and with an interesting salad and everyone loves tater tots. Great and perfectly cooked scallops appetizer. The space is amazing and I can't imagine how wonderful it would be on a spring day with the windows up.

okAaQ0gueeqQqNK3tXln4A.text: I came here w/ one of my favorites this past Thursday night; after walking out I can declare Eleven as one of my favorite restaurants in Pittsburgh.  We made reservations for 7 PM and were promptly seated; most of the crowd seemed to be of an older demographic, the average age in the restaurant was easily at least 20 years older than me.  I walked in with the intention of ordering their four course tasting menu with the wine pairing, but changed my mind the last second because I really wanted to try their Wagyu Beef Carpaccio.  I ended up ordering their Elysian Fields Farm Lamb and she ordered their Heritage Farms Pork (all of the Big Burrito restaurants push the fact that they use sustainable ingredients, as is evident from the fact that the locations where all proteins are sourced are included in the dish names).  The Carpaccio was as good as expected; would I order it again?  Depends on my mood, and who I'm with.  I've realized I have a larger than average-for-an-Asian hankering for raw and cured meats.  I knew if I didn't get their tasting menu I'd be deciding between their lamb and duck dish (my two favorite land-based proteins), but our server told me the lamb was his favorite dish hands down, so I took his word for it and had it medium rare.  I know some people complain about lamb having a "lamb-y" taste, but this lamb was well sourced and well cooked with maximum tenderness and flavor without the off-putting flavor of cheaper cuts of meat.  The roasted root vegetables had just the perfect bite; not too soft which would result in mushiness and not too hard from being undercooked.  The polenta was absolutely delicious and paired perfectly with both the protein and the vegetable.  The pork was a giant chop served on the bone, cooked to a suggested medium rare.  The taste of well sourced ingredients is especially evident when it comes to protein as animals raised outside the typical inhumane dark and cramped living conditions have a richer flavor with a better mouthfeel.  The sliced sweet potatoes were cooked well but their texture didn't resonate with me as a perfect match with the crunchiness of the apple strips and the meatiness of the pork.  Everything else was spot on though.  For dessert we split their banana cream pie.  The deconstructed pie came with house-made banana graham crackers topped with dulce de leche mousse with a banana brulee on the side.  The graham crackers were a bit crunchier than expected but were perfect to cut the sweetness and creaminess of the mousse.  The banana brulee itself of course was a wonderful textural experience with the caramelized exterior of the banana cutting into the sweetness of the soft fruit.  When you do go to Eleven, make sure you are in the mindset and mood to eating simple yet elegantly prepared quality food.  Food doesn't taste as good when you're distracted and the dishes Eleven serves up are worthy of your full attention.

photos.caption: Photo of Eleven - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Wagyu Beef Carpaccio
Photo of Eleven - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Elysian Fields Farm Lamb: polenta, root vegetables, sage, lamb jus
Photo of Eleven - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Heritage Farms Pork: apple, sweet potato, cauliflower, red onion mostarda

iia4glme5xHVn4gZGXpRFQ.text: I've been to Eleven a few times and it has consistently been a great experience. My last meal was the lamb chops. They were excellent and prepared perfectly. I highly recommend eleven for a date or small group.

ni6rU5eNB-iN44qNimTRlA.text: I was in town for work and came here with colleagues.  I had one of the best risottos I've ever had (it was a special and had rhubarb and hazelnuts.)  Everyone else enjoyed their meals as well.  It was great for a group.

7Q0HxwMJOYAS_Uo7te9-Gw.text: I had only been in Pittsburgh for about 10 minutes and I NEEDED food. Being that the city is pretty busy with hockey fans trying to get dinner before the Winter Classic I had no idea where to even start to look for a place to eat. Google maps said that there was a place to eat within sight of my hotel lobby - that would work.  Walking in it looked VERY upscale and it was too early for the dining room, but we could eat in the bar area. Given that we were already in hockey fan gear that was a more comfortable environment anyway.  The food was perfect, very tasty soft pretzels and they had Blue Coat gin which I am always in search for.  The only reason that I could not give Eleven five stars is that once we had our food the service seemed to disappear.  While we wanted a casual meal we did have a only a short time before we had to head to the stadium. The delay in getting our check and getting on our way kind of tarnished the overall experience to that point. Maybe it was the fact that we were not for the home team.  In the end I would eat there again if I was even in Pittsburgh.

aPYEGcpX452u96zTllvo8A.text: A weak 4 star, imo. Some dishes are excellent, while others are fairly ordinary. Given that it is a pricy restaurant (most entrees are around $30, most wine glasses are north of 12), this is a disappointment.   There are several better, less expensive high-end restaurants in Pittsburgh, such as Spoon and Legume. I'll go to these, and I doubt I will be back at Eleven.  The place is quite nice, high ceiling, comfortable tables, relaxed but elegant. I probably prefer the room there to the new space of Legume in Oakland. Many suit people, but not exclusively.  Foodwise, this was definitely a mixed evening. - the lamb is delicious, a clear winner, 5 star. The medium rare meat is very tasty, the polenta provides a nice balance to some of the sweeter vegetables, e.g., onions. ($36) - tuna tartare was also very good, fresh and crisp. 5 star (12) - soft shell crab was pretty interesting: I enjoyed the light and slightly spicy sauce it was in. 4 star. - the pork was on the drier side - not remarkable. The slice was thin (whence the dryness), and the vegetables did not do much to highlight its tastes. 3 star - foie gras (in the tasting menu) was far from being the best I've had (but I am picky about that), the chocolate bar (basically, a "croquant") was on the heavier side. 3 star.   Two of us had the tasting menu. The portions are smaller, so you don't feel stuffed by the end of the dinner. On the other hand, if I end up there again, I'll just go for the lamb, perhaps with an appetizer.  I should also add that the menu is fairly conservative.

8UvaUGdqJRNxHaI6vN2Nww.text: The food here was just alright, but the service was excellent! I also liked the interior, but I don't find their dishes to be as impressive as umi and soba ( I know it's different cuisine but just a general feeling), so I wouldn't return.

E_KqcKXYfkllRPtidSvhXw.text: Fantastic experience from start to finish! The restaurant is absolutly beautiful, and our server was funny, attentive, and very knowledge!  My husband and I came here on our honeymoon, and were celebrated with a glass of champagne right away.    We ordered the Pork Belly as a starter, and loved it.  For an entree, I had the beef tenderloin, and my husband had the duck. Both were hands down the most tender pieces of respective meats that we've EVER had.  We kept going with dessert; a cheese plate and the Banana Cream Pie (which isn't really a pie at all).  They even had written "Congratulations" on a piece of dark chocolate, laid across the Banana Cream.   The portions were very large, which means we left VERY full, since we tried, and loved, every bite!  No detail was missed, which made for a truly spectacular evening!

Hgwise9qIRi06j_0uJv_Sw.text: Great lunch spot and quite compared to all the other spots in the strip. Hanger Steak is amazing and end it with the Candy Bar desert... Great wait staff!

G2si8xwDIhdLH2xDwYFa4Q.text: Good but not great.  I enjoyed my meal but was not wowed.  Better than Salt, but when you consider the food for the cost not worth it.  If you enjoy trendy wine bar type places this would be a great hang out, the bar was packed and the wine options seemed endless.  I do have to say the desserts looked outstanding; it took every ounce of willpower not to try them.

CcQaLE3Dq5VTvOK8lS657Q.text: We had late reservations for the restaurant so we arrived a bit early to have cocktails and appetizers at the bar.  I had a vodka martini (okay, two) with goat cheese stuffed olives - delicious - and my companion had a bourbon and coke.  The cocktails were well-poured.  We had the rock-shrimp appetizer - nice, light breading and the accompnaying dipping sauce was slightly sweet with a little kick.  We were seated a little early and our server was perfectly lovely, offering helpful tips about the menu and wine pairings.  To start, I had the oysters along with a lovely glass of prosecco, my partner had the scallops.  The beau-soleil oysters were served with a mignonette and homemade hotsauce - a little sweet, a little briny, with a dash of the hot sauce - it was perfection.  The scallops were a big hit - grits and jalapeno relish were lovely contrasting elements to the sweetness of the scallops and saltiness of the ham.  I had the seafood tasting for dinner - the golden tilefish was light and lemony, the crabcake decadent and the salmon (which I was not particularly excited about) was just a big WOW - smoky, perfectly moist, I couldn't get enough of it!  My companion had the pork chop and, given the speed with which the generous portion disappeared from his plate, loved it.  We shared the frozen dark chocolate ganache - caramel fluff, coconut sorbet - sinful, divine.  We left eleven full, slightly drunk and very happy.

VAESfibg2Bt9t9or6CEtZw.text: Seriously 0 stars.  This was the worst experience and meal I have ever had in my life. In fact it was so bad that I decided to sign up for Yelp just to let you know that you should not waste your time much less money here!

ZCV20nwj2QJlF2ocg8bKgQ.text: We arrived Sunday night at 6:00 without reservations.  About 25% of the tables inside were filled but we were told that we would have to eat outside, that it was covered and had fans.  What we were not told was that the sun made the outside seating too hot to be coomfortable--it shone directly into our eyes.  We ordered little meal, ate quickly becasue we were too hot, and left in about an hour.  When we left the resaurant inside was still only 25% full.  It was obvious that we weren't wecome without a reservation--snooty restaurant.  We were well dressed (suit and tie) so that wan't the problem.  Why should we go again?  I don't know.  We were driving by and stopped on a whim--a big mistake we won't repeat.

5Lr1-yhghYAWrGAuI5e8rQ.text: I was really impressed with Eleven.  Great, knowledge server.  Awesome wine list, great food.  Nice ambience.  I have spent most of my years in Pittsburgh.  After years of having excellent food in 100s of different places, and saying"yea, Pittsburgh is awesome, but they don't have good restaurants"' after  being gone for 5 years and getting back, the changes have been good.  In my book Eleven is a standout.  I'll be back!

7OWCfEZv9FJwQajb2PWC6g.text: My friend and I were in the area for the Winter Classic. We picked ELEVEN for linner (lunch/dinner) because it came up in our search for an American fare restaurant located close to our hotel. Boy did we luck out! The layout/space is distinct and the decor is modern. The dress code is in the range of smart casual to business informal. However, we were in jeans and our game gear and felt comfortable. OK, now to the important part ... the food. We shared the homemade soft pretzels with cheddar cheese-beer sauce and Maldon sea salt for an appetizer and I had the Eleven Burger -- short rib & chuck, braised veal, black pepper bacon, crispy onions and blue cheese with fries on the side. Quality ingredients, tasty flavor combinations and decent prices. We also ordered cocktails that were strong and good. The service was great in the beginning, but after our main course it was poor. We had to wait a looooong time to get  our check.

7S8tj_w31N9RMVa7r-p9bg.text: Disappointed with my first meal at Eleven. Wife enjoyed the Curried Chicken and Sweet Potato Soup and her Salmon entree. Her Baby Kale and Brussel Sprout Caesar Salad had no brussel sprouts and no croutons. My tasting menu had a decent Tuna Tartare. The Striped Bass was solid. Nothing special. Good flavors, but nothing I would order again or lead me back to the restaurant.  The lamb temp was off.  It was cooled for too long, and the portion was tiny - even for a tasting menu. The only bites felt cold in my mouth. It was overcooked as well; however, the flavor was excellent.  I would order that dish again as an entree.  My tasting menu dessert and my wife's warm chocolate cake were both delicious.  Every touch to both desserts were amazing.  We only complained about the salad issue. Our server was nice and apologized.  She said that the brussel sprouts will be on the salad the next time we order it, and that was it. I would have expected a manager to stop by for an apology or for the restaurant to offer to comp something.  We ordered two glasses of champagne, the salad, a dessert, corkage of $20, two coffees, etc.  Something beyond the server apology would have been appreciated. I have no desire to go back at this point, but if i were forced there for any reason, I would order the Lamb and make sure to get a dessert.

C7Tt7eNhk3uTX90QKzrinQ.text: I made a reservation for my husbands birthday, when we walked in on a Saturday night - this place was only half full. Even when I had told them about my husbands birthday, they gave us the worst possible table in restaurant even when it wasn't full. I had to ask for a better table. Drinks were average - food was horrible and the service wasn't up to the mark. I've been to muchhh better places which are as expensive. This is a definite NO, please don't go here for special occasions.

oYqRI-d0J8X1K68VXFUfAQ.text: Went there for dinner with a client and it was a horrible experience. My fish was ruined and her steak was ruined. Wait staff was unattentive and entire experience was so sad. Very embarrassing for me. Plenty of choices in Pittsburgh for upscale dinners so skip this place at all cost.

Z8i1tYkf8iLQrTWnoQKaNQ.text: This is my favorite big burritto joint.  I've been here several times and never been disappointed.  The valet parking is  helpful, however should be complimentary given the cost of the place.  The interior is gorgeous with an open kitchen, great bar area, tall ceilings and private area upstairs.  The wine selection is better than most and overpriced as is the standard.  The service is as good as any other place in the city from the host to the server to  the bartender.  Dinner starts with an amouse bouche (sp?), which last night was some type of parmesan crisp with a pea mash on top (not that good really and an odd grainy texture).  Then they have a great assortment of bread they make in house.  We started last night with  a lamb taco which was perfectly cooked seasoned tender lamb on a corn tortilla with a nice sauce.  I ordered the filet, which was a prime cut filet cooked perfectly served with  a mushroom black truffle bread pudding (the bread pudding was quite heavy and except for the mushrooms pretty bland).  It's also accompanied with root vegetables in a wine reduction.  My friend ordered the seafood tasting, which we shared.  It was a small piece of salmon cooked well and seasoned nicely with  two shrimp with the head on.  The shrimp was amazing.  It was delicate and had a great flavor, tasted like they pulled them  out of the  water minutes earlier.  The crabcakes were a little below average with too much breading and a little overcooked.  A special shout out to the server Tim who was great and a pro.  Next time I'll try the chef tasting menu and if a group occassion comes up I hear the chef's table in the kitchen is quite an experience.  All in all this restaurant can stack up in any city.

z1yVfwfIJoY5hZxRZ7J_Bw.text: I've been to Eleven several times now, in both the Tavern side and the formal dining room.  The Tavern side is my favorite...lighter food, more casual, good times.  The regular restaurant side is good too and the food is fantastic, but it tends toward formal dining with service that can be a bit too attentive.  Just depends what type of evening you are looking for.  The menu changes quite a bit but some of my favorites have been the potato and goat cheese peirogies, the crab cake sandwich, and the soft pretzels.

GwB0yYopeYkqO6VThWpbmg.text: This was our first visit to Pittsburgh so we were relying on Yelp to find us a good restuarant, which I must say it did. The Eleven is a terrific location with easy parking. The ambience is delightful, upscale cozy contemporary. The wait staff are wonderful and ours was passionate about food. The food was both interesting and delicious.  Our party of four, all oyster lovers, were very pleased with theirs.  We had two different entrees, the fish sampler which featured some kind of white fish that I cannot remember, salmon and crab cakes, the cakes being the best of the three; all crab, almost no breading,  with mild seasoning. We all agreed that the pasta with mushrooms and other delictable vegetables and perfectly sauced was better . The best part of the meal for me was the lava cake dessert. Though you can get this everywhere now, I have never had a better one. It was devine.  I would definitely return to this place.

pC_hcsRAjLtxeYu1pqTR4Q.text: on the whole Eleven was awesome, why? a) i was in pittsburgh, and this is probably as fine as fine dining gets in this city. b) perfect weather outside allowed us to enjoy our dinner on the 2nd floor deck overlooking the river. c) chef's tasting menu (4 courses biatch).   Onto the food. started with an extra dirty martini on the suggestion of my pittsburghian friend. it was gross. i do not do extra dirty. but fear not, they had a great summer wheat on tap. the chef's tasting menu started with a spicy tuna tartar and a salmon carpaccio. yes. i love both of these things. oh i forgot, as a compliment from the chef they served us bluefish on a piece of toast. it was fishy. back to the chef's menu. the second course was halibut over a risotto with mushrooms. The best thing about this was that it was the same portion as my friend who ordered it as his main. by this time i was pretty full. the next dish was lamb which was served medium rare. it was excellent no doubt. (sidenote: i tried my friend's seared tuna which was equally awesome). lastly was some strawberry tart on a funnel cake. apparently they burned the funnel cake the first time so it took forever to come out. oh i almost forgot we got apps. the calamari is amazing, the avocado fries were nothing to write home about, the pierogis were pretty weak, and i wanna say there was one more but it coudln't have been great cause i dont remember it. all in all, it was $80 including tax and tip.

GHoZLRc1iMt0gAhFjHaShg.text: my favorite pittsburgh restaurant. please get the beef tenderloin or the seafood tasting... delicious! for a cheaper deal, go for lunch on a weekday

0jA0UXuMSCanIgNWHpfgZw.text: I am a big fan of the Big Burrito family of restaurants, of which Eleven is evidently supposed to be the flagship (the S class of Big Burrito).  I have only been here for Lunch, so take this review for what it is worth, it may not apply to the dinner menu.  I have eaten here twice for lunch, once with my wife, and another time for a non cost controlled work related lunch.  I would have to say that in neither case was I impressed with the quality of the product.  In my most recent meal, I had a scallop appetizer in which the scallops had a very palpable fishy taste.  I half wanted to skip the appetizer altogether--and I certainly did not get sick, but it really wasn't very yummy.  The service is great (really it is very good from knowledge of the dishes to the knowledge of the wines), the decor and the ambience lovely, and for all that I know the dinner quality is great, but I have been underwhelmed by lunch.  If you eat there, I hope you have a better experience given the price.

NJUeBNG5XecNvcMy_xaTyA.text: yum!  seafood tasting menu.  good wine list.  what more can i say?  oh!  the service is always great.  only not so great thing i've had there is the lobster bisque - too salty!

HcIOnFa3RDhGLgvmnTZJMg.text: I thought Eleven was really good. I'm not going to get into the decor because it is what you would expect at a pricier restaurant. What I will say is that I didn't know butter nut squash and brussel spouts could even be paired together but it worked beautifully. With that said make sure you try the Elysian Fields Farm Lamb if you're a lamb buff like myself. My girlfiend had the Seafood Tasting and I have nothing but positive things to say about. It comes with crab cakesk, shrimp & grits, and salmon. Everything was delicious. If you're starving then the plate size may not be up to par with your appetite so make sure you order some apps before your entree. I'm not from Pittsburgh but this place is definitely worth a try.

ZHpuMnT07rJx90TPOuZOVw.text: I went to Eleven with high hopes, having read good things about it on this site and elsewhere. The food was very good, and the service excellent. Two serious problems lead to a three-star rating instead of something higher: 1) white wine served so cold it had very little flavor and 2) it was VERY noisy. The open kitchen means lots of noise; normal conversation was difficult. If you are looking for a restful evening, a quiet dinner, this is decidedly not the place to go. On the other hand, if you like a busy, party feel, it might be just the thing. They could easily fix the wine service problem, but I don't think they will be trying to make the restaurant more quiet.

fNYu6Wdp9EIoZUGzTaYFbQ.text: great for upscale cocktails and fabulous dinner.  tenderloin w lobster is my personal favorite. considered pricey on pgh scale, but is what to expect for all other locales. great wine list.

aFlKYmxxuRVnRT9tzdPaKg.text: The space inside has been very nicely renovated. I told them we were celebrating an anniversary, so they put us in a little balcony booth. The staff were very nice. We skipped right to entrees, getting the pork chop and chicken. I could only eat half the pork chop, but the dish was very good. Hubby finished the chicken. We ordered the warm chocolate cake with ice cream for dessert, and it came with a little chocolate "happy anniversary" plaque. The check came with coffee truffles. It's an expensive restaurant but worth the price for a once-a-year celebratory dinner. Hubby wanted me to mention that although there is music playing in the background, it is not too loud to have a conversation. Also, the porch and balcony look like nice places to eat with all the plants and greenery. Get your parents to treat you here the next time they're in town.  Edit: I wish they just brought your leftovers to your table. We forgot to stop at the maitre de stand, and no one asked on our way out. I really would have liked to finish my pork chop.

3SgcL2vC4PhksEWr0hsKXA.text: So, full disclosure, we tried to get reservations to the Butcher and the Rye during our Pittsburgh trip to celebrate our one-year anniversary. When we couldn't we looked around and found Eleven and I'm so glad that we did. What clinched the deal was browsing the wine menu online--I saw that they had Pinot noir from Kunde, one of the wineries we visit on our honeymoon in Sonoma! It was a sign. And so to Eleven we went.  The restaurant doesn't look like much from the outside, but the interior is dominated by a large wine storage enclosure that you can see throughout the restaurant. They offer coat check which was convenient on this particular rainy evening. We were seated immediately in the area to the right of reception.   We ordered two glasses of the Kunde (of course) and the Three Greens salad to share as a starter. I'm not often impressed with salads, but this one was delicious! The red peppers are chopped small and dispersed throughout, and the goat cheese vinaigrette is heavenly. Creamy, tart and perfectly coating the vegetables. The plate is large enough to share for sure. Someone also brought around a basket of bread for us to take from. I got the sourdough, but our favorite was the focaccia my husband got.   For our entrees, I had the lamb and my husband had the strip steak. Both meats were cooked medium, just as we requested them. There was some variation in my lamb near the bone, where it tended toward medium-rare but that's difficult to mitigate and I didn't mind. My lamb was well-seasoned and savory, with the raisins, carrots and other components lending a complementary sweetness. The parsnip croutons were interesting--sort of banana bread-ish in their taste and density. I thought they were delicious but I admit I set them off to the side to eat last because they were so sweet instead of eating them with the rest of the components on the plate.  My husband's steak was well-crusted in pepper and served with a delicious sauce. The one bite that I got was delicious, spicy and tender.  Since we virtuously skipped the appetizer in favor of salad, of course we had to order dessert. The warm chocolate cake with ice cream was good but not remarkable. I'd probably try something else if I returned. It's smaller but enough to share.   Overall, a wonderful meal.

RUkwvX3sYVAesKTxC_yLwQ.text: My standard order: Roasted asparagus Strip steak entree  Moscow mule  When I find something delicious I don't like to deviate. However each time I go I say I should try something different. Maybe next time...

ROko7AUbDf7kzLDDAS1Y5A.text: I've only ever been to Eleven for brunch, but the experience is always wonderful. The service is here is top notch without being stuffy and you really feel pampered, which is a nice change from a lot of other places that try to be upscale, but don't quite follow through with the food. For what you get, I think the prix fixe brunch is worth it. The Bloody Mary here is pretty good, as are the gin cocktails I've tried. My favorite part about brunch is probably the basket of mini breads. The food isn't super unique for brunch - I think we've tried most things on the menu now, but they do a good job. With the solid food, great service, and spaced out tables that make conversation easy, Eleven is easily one of the best choices for a leisurely brunch in Pittsburgh.

szLBJqvnbl_Yi4Leg8_1HQ.text: My wife and I were in Pittsburgh during October '18 for a meeting.  We ate twice at Eleven, returning b/c we enjoyed it so much.  The food is superb--excellent ingredients, imaginatively prepared and beautifully presented.  The tasting menu was especially nice, but plenty to share (we over-ordered the first time).  Very convenient to hotels near convention center.  Highly recommended.  Wonderful, personable service as well.

rJ9J-m_AzyCOG5OLLTHISw.text: The service at this restaurant is extremely rude. I came here with a group of friends for a birthday brunch and was met with eye-rolls and condescending remarks. Granted, I was in a large group that decided at the last minute to eat at this restaurant. However, I would expect to be told that we had to wait for tables to open up. Instead, the staff told us "good luck" sarcastically and the waiter commented that this was "bullshit." I honestly think they were being a bit racist. Would not recommend and really disappointed.

ozvHiT8_iaM3bNJ0EtT9nw.text: A great place for a date or special celebration.   The hand-crafted cocktails were delish and the portions weren't overwhelming. The appetizers are not of "shareable" style, but my Scottish Salmon was just enough.   On a late Friday evening, it wasn't terribly crowded so that was definitely an added plus.

mSUpEqPH0Ir-Kc3LYFX-1w.text: We sat in the bar after the lunch crunch.  At that point it wasn't busy.  Service and food were good.  We had crispy calamari and split a crab cake sandwich.  The sandwich was large; the crab cakes were mostly crab with little filler.  Although they were good, as was our overall experience, those crab cakes could have had more flavor.  It wasn't a bargain, but the ambiance, service, and food give me reasons to return.

KWfSPiH3VBIV1SjnTEJyfg.text: Good for happy hour!   The first time I came to Eleven was for lunch in December and I wasn't that impressed. The second time was today for happy hour with two friends. No wait and it was a great day, so we sat outside. I wasn't in the mood to drink, but friends got the Ruby Red and red sangria which they both enjoyed. We shared the oysters, Blue Bay mussels (comes with kielbasa), calamari, and onion rings. The oysters were tiny and salty, not exactly how I like my oysters, but still decent. (No need for the big plate though.) Mussels were good; I especially enjoyed the soft center of the fried sourdough. The calamari was great, no complaints. I thought the onion rings were just okay; I usually prefer my onion rings to be more substantial (thicker). For the price, the portions of the mussels and calamari were large, but not so much for the onion rings and small oysters. Still, Eleven is a good option for happy hour if you're Downtown!   Taste | 4 Atmosphere | 3.5 Presentation | 3.5 Service | 3  OVERALL | 3.5

photos.caption: Photo of Eleven - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. candy bar
Photo of Eleven - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. upstairs
Photo of Eleven - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. tuna tartare

6nkMX5xWqxYkaaC6H2-ryA.text: The food was five stars, the service was barely there. I came with a large party that was seated upstairs. The waitress never introduced herself,  and we never heard any specials, or recommendation. We were never offered bread. When we asked for it, it came a minute before the meal. The food was basically thrown at us. We were never checked on, never refilled. Then came the bills without a word. Whats worse is that it wasn't even that busy. The waiter/waitresses stood at the bar and alternated between staring at us and making jokes.  The lack of service definitely overshadowed the food. We were very disappointed.

VFNEWfyqSiwMpLSncCjBpg.text: We were visiting from out of town, and coming to celebrate a birthday. We made reservations a week early, and were happy with the reviews. When we arrived 1hr early to get drinks and relax, they informed us that our table was already ready! We still stayed in the bar area with friends, and enjoyed the drinks.  Our server was excellent, and the food was great. We would definitely recommend this to anyone in the Area looking for great food.  Cons: it was kinda dark for is to see the menu.

photos.caption: Photo of Eleven - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

6cnDd992rmysIyPGrhqJdA.text: 3.5ish for me.   I really loved this place...except for the service, which really dragged the place down on both visits. The food was fantastic and the portions were larger than I'd anticipated.  The bread selections were delicious.  The seafood sampler was top notch.   The decor was pretty and comfortable at the same time.  We were upstairs and practically had the place to ourselves.   Which is why I was so sad about the SLOOOOOOWWWW service.  Everything  from drinks to food to boxes to the check took a long time and it just seemed like our server showed up at all the wrong times.  They were polite and all, but absent a lot and not super on top of the flow of service. There is parking across the street and a coat check at the door, but plan to be there a while.

CCbOc_No9-xm8cvE_ceK_Q.text: I agree with those who say the food is bland. Disappointed in a lot of the places I recently raved over in the Pittsburg area. Just not what it used to be. Over priced for a place that is now lackluster. The wine list is swell, the atmosphere hasn't changed. However, the dining area is quickly becoming dated. Sort of reminds me of an oversized hotel dining experience. I wouldn't put it passed them to start putting lava cake on the desert menu. Sad for a place that was once my favorite for an upscale night of dining.

0fIlOloE8p1w5TGbq5tj_w.text: Was invited here for a work dinner, and went despite knowing the menu had nothing (nothing!) vegetarian on it. The waiter was nice, and suggested that they make their pasta dish without meat on it, and while I generally don't like to do that, I ordered it. It was good, but I don't know how I would have felt about paying that much (had I been paying). The desserts, however, were really great, although the waiter sort of pushed our group into getting a big platter of them that we then struggled to finish.  My favorite part of the meal: the moscow mule. You must have it.

kEChb01SHmMV2EMmACb0NQ.text: This restaurant was amazing! We ate the swordfish and pork for dinner. Both were excellent! The prices were reasonable for the sizes of each of the dishes. Also, the bread they offered before our meal was excellent. It was three types of freshly baked bread they made in house. The waiter was knowledgeable about the history of the restaurant and menu. The service was great. The atmosphere is elegant yet casual. I would highly recommend!

photos.caption: Photo of Eleven - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. The swordfish and pork was delicious!

m5XgOSimhJkbTZO0UTUbOg.text: Went for dinner and ordered the tasting menu with wine pairings. The meat menu was superb, the vegetarian menu was inconsistent and left something to be desired. Wines paired well.   Drinks: ELEVEN mules cocktail - Moscow mule made with homemade ginger beer. Fresh, strong ginger flavor and just sweet enough. Recommend.  First Course:  Tuna Tartare (meat tasting) -- tender and well-seasoned. Bf loved it.  Roasted Beet Salad (veggie tasting) -- The endive in the salad was overpoweringly bitter. The best part was a piece of yellow beet paired with the pistachio topping. Overall, mine was just not good. Neither of us wanted to finish it.  Second Course: Wow! Both were great.  The Swordfish (meat tasting)-- cooked so well that my bf kept commenting how much he liked it despite swordfish being his least favorite fish. Eggplant (veggie tasting) -- my favorite dish of the night. Perfectly fried cubes of eggplant sat in a bed of Israeli couscous which surprised me at being nearly as delicious. Even the julienned carrot garnish complimented the dish.   Third (Entree) Course: Elysian Fields Farm Lamb Chops (meat tasting). The smoked lamb belly was reportedly delicious and my bf couldn't get enough. But he likes lamb on the rarer side of medium rare which this was not. The waiter replaced the lamb with a beautiful half-plate presentation. The meat was still a little over cooked for his preference but it was a lot better. Everything was seasoned very well.  Casereccia pasta with kale pesto, burrata, olives, fried chickpeas and roasted peppers (veggie tasting). I had high hopes for this, but we were both underwhelmed. The chickpeas actually detracted from the dish. The kale pesto was fresh and green but not rich or flavorful.   Dessert: Black Forest Torte with mascarpone ice cream and cacao nibs (which added so much!) -- was not dry at all and paired well with the crunch of the cacao nibs and the creamy ice cream.  Lemon Cheesecake -- okay but I think it was ricotta-based and that's not my jam. I usually love cheesecake, though, so I was disappointed.   I do want to note that the service was excellent. Our waiter was attentive and friendly. We were offered bread several times.   In summary, this is an amazing restaurant for carnivores 5/5. It's less reliable for vegetarians 3/5.

photos.caption: Photo of Eleven - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Eggplant - fried cubes with Israeli couscous
Photo of Eleven - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Tuna tartare
Photo of Eleven - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Black Forest Torte - birthday edition!

DsCGrHVlRcd4oG8Wvh-nfw.text: I've been wanting to come here for a while. I finally had the chance on mothers day. I have to say I went in with high expectations and while it was good it wasn't great. I felt our waiter was a bit frazzled and slow at first but seemed to settle in as brunch progressed.  I went with beignets for my app which were fresh and perfect. To drink I went with the blood orange cocktail. While it was strong it wasn't as flavorful as I had been hoping it would be. I also must mention the fruit bowl on the kids menu. It was fresh and perfectly ripe and I stole a few berries from my boy. My entree was huevos rancheros. The flavors were bold I really enjoyed it. I also had a mimosa. It was perfectly mixed with about 2/3 champaign and 1/3 oj. I look forward to coming back and trying dinner. Hopefully service doesn't start out as slow.

photos.caption: Photo of Eleven - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Smoked pork huevos ranchero.
Photo of Eleven - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Kids fruit bowl.
Photo of Eleven - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Beignets with lemon.

Vt5M28wqceVmW3NUny2GIQ.text: In short: Everything about our experience was perfect! I will definitely be returning to Eleven in the near future! Read on if you want details.  Booking our reservation: We called and were cheerfully greeted with a "what's the occasion?" to which we replied it was a celebratory dinner. More on this later. :)  When we arrived, all of the staff were friendly and welcoming. We were instantly comfortable. We did dress up a little bit but did not feel like we would have been shunned had we been a bit more casual. The whole place somehow balances elegance and comfort. It has many different zones, both inside and out, each with their own unique feel.   Our waiter was so nice and made sure we were completely satisfied with our meal. We neither felt rushed nor ignored. As wine fans, but not quite connoisseurs,  he was able to answer any question we had about their excellent wine list. Personally, I found their selection to be fairly priced and of good quality. Again, our waiter helped us pick great wines, at the right price, that also went well with our meal.   I ordered the pork chops with some Trefethen merlot, and my girlfriend ordered the salmon with some Albarei Albrino.   The wine and bread arrived very shortly after ordering. The wines were served at the perfect temperature in beautiful glassware. They offered three types of bread, each of which was delicious. I would have loved if the bread was slightly warmer. I'm really nit picking here though. I'm finding it next to impossible to criticize Eleven.   We were only a few sips into our wine when our meals arrived. I was blown away by how quickly our food arrived. IT truly was impressively fast.... and delicious!  The salmon was both crispy and flakey at the same time. 10/10! The pork chops were succulent and flavorful. Not even the slightest hint of dryness was detected. I even ordered more bread so that I could soak up every last drop of juice left on the plate. It was incredible. 10/10!  The desert menu was solid. We split an Adelsheim dessert wine and the creme brulee. Both were fantastic. One of the best creme brulee's I have had in recent history. Now, remember when I mentioned the "what's the occasion" question? Well, they even went so far as to include a little chocolate "congratulations" sign with our desert. Unbelievable.   Our bill was topped off with a sweet, tropical fruit treat, and thank you from our waiter, and a fairly reasonable number at the bottom of the receipt. Obviously, it would always be nice to see a smaller number, but for the incredible service and food that we enjoyed, the experience of an evening at Eleven is well worth the price.  I highly recommend going to Eleven for your next special night out in the 'burgh!  Cheers!

6smHdS21FhacG0rGlTd0Vw.text: Basically in the shadow of what I am guessing is the convention center (I'm now from around here!), this place was a GREAT find.  We got here at 9:45pm after walking over after a Penguins game...too late to be seated in the dining room so we sat in the bar lounge at a high top table.   There food was PHENOMENAL!  The soft pretzel /cheese app was fresh and hot and delicious.  My scallops app was done to perfection; not overcooked and rubbery! Yea! The black pepper gnocchi were die for and my daughter's seafood sampler was so, so good.    The service was impeccable.   The bathrooms were pretty fancy too!

photos.caption: Photo of Eleven - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Hubby&#39;s halibut sandwich. Simple, yet tasty.
Photo of Eleven - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Perfect scallops... Mmmm
Photo of Eleven - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Black pepper gnocchi. Tender and amazing!

TBCWqcguwhyl-wmj2eqc_A.text: I chose Eleven as my Birthday dinner, as I have done over the years.  The food is always amazing and this year didn't disappoint.  The reason for the 3 stars was the service.  The service has always been superb and this year just felt a little flat/off.  Nothing major just not at the level we have had in the past. But to get back to the food review..... we had 1.5 dz fresh oysters and they were so delish.  The vinegrette served with them is so good!!!!  I had a kale and brussel sprout salad and hubs had the potato and bacon soup.  I think we both licked our plates clean!!!  For entrees, he had the hangar steak and I had the black bass.  We didn't even talk as we were so engrossed in devouring our meals :) We took dessert home to enjoy - I had the candy bar cake which was a mix of chocolate and peanut butter with choc malt ice cream.  He had a banana cream concoction.  Both divine!!!! Plan to go - I've never been disappointed with the food.

H4tOIDFzuMz92L87thgVgw.text: This review is just for brunch  ...and what a brunch it was! For $25, you get a little pastry basket, appetizer, entree, and cocktail. For the quality of food, this is quite a steal!  Compared to other prix fixe brunches in Pittsburgh (e.g. Park Brugge) I found their menu more interested and diverse. Duck hash and Oysters for appetizers, and entrees ranging from classics (eggs benedict, steak and eggs) to less traditional (veal burger, smoked lamb heuvos rancheros). Similarly for cocktails - mimosas, bloody marys, and their own refreshing cucumbery twist on a moscow mule.  While everything was good, none of it was outstanding - I feel the execution of the dishes left more to be desired. Flavors were simple, and lacked the "wow" factor I get from other high end restaurants in the area.  While it was a great deal for $25, I personally prefer the Brugge restaurants for my Sunday prix fixe brunch. Same price, but I feel the quality of food there is a little better. Nonetheless, it was a solid choice for brunch!

uj58wNNYNXbmaRvKFWJFJA.text: Just ok, I sat at the bar and the bartender was attentive however I really do believe the tequila was left out of my margarita all together. No seriously I believe my $12 margarita was VIRGIN! The food was just alright. Nothing to write home about. Wouldn't visit again.

-m2IIlVm1hkWbgkqUACSUQ.text: We came here for a bach party. The group ordered the beef tongue, yellowtail, pierogies, and some sort of rock shrimp app for the table. Surprisingly I really liked the beef tongue and I knew I'd love the yellowtail. I was trying to decide how much I wanted to eat and was debating on a trio of salmon, crab cake, and scallops OR just ordering two apps of scallops and crab cakes. I chose the app portions, but two others in the group split the trio and got PERFECTLY portioned meals for each of them. The app portions with their accompaniments ended up being a little too much food. The food was good, but not fab. The initial apps we ordered for the group were actually better. Everyone seemed to enjoy their food and the atmosphere. We all wanted the pics on the wall in the bathroom - very...different.

-YMu5FHhXJX6Z1uUqp-mUw.text: Just had their sunday brunch and it was fantastic!!!! it was easy to get a reservation but it was on a post steeler game snowy sunday morning. We decided to do the Prix fix which is $25 and includes an appetizer, entree, a pastry basket and a cocktail. Totally worth it!!!!   I got the blood orange mimosa and the flute was large (just the way i like it) for my appetizer i got the crispy brussel sprouts (sans the anchovies) and they were AMAZING!!  my BF got the oysters with their house made hot sauce and they were "orgasmic" we both got omelettes and the portions were large and the quality of the food was top notch. Our server was very friendly and he was attentive. He even inquired if i wanted a meatless substitute for my entree. Eleven is definitely my favourite restaurant in Pittsburgh as far as consistency goes. The brunch just confirmed it.

F90oTX_ku6pzDTxciU5Sjg.text: Although I have been to Eleven for dinner (very good) my favorite thing is their Brunch.  They have such a fantastic bakery basket and their pre-fixe is a good deal considering the high quality of items that you receive.  The only thing that is hit or miss sometimes is the service which could be improved given the fact that this is a high end dining establishment.

VcS9kWRAXyUmxqAmyJhu3A.text: We had a great evening all around. We were warmly greeted and had an attentive waiter. The meal was well paced and the food was inventive and delicious. We look forward to returning.

RFgHhQrNcs3tpT-knBpy_A.text: Wonderful Night out!! Dinner was Fabulous!! Five of us dined. We were seated promptly. The service was great. Our server new the menu well and everyone ordered both first and second courses. We all had different items, and all gave the meal a huge thumbs up! Two of us had the Foie Gras, and it was excellent. We asked our server to recommend a wine to accompany the Foie Gras, and he suggested a very nice French Semillon at: $11 a glass that was not only wonderful, but the best value on their list. Our table shared two desserts, with one knocking it out of the park. Don't miss ordering the "Hazel Nut Candy Bar" dessert. It was magnificent in both taste and presentation. Thanks, Eleven for a great night!!

X2kbjvPrYhR74wKEG-IeXw.text: Great meal, excellent atmosphere.   The gnocchi was fantastic as well as the soft pretzels.  The peanut butter dessert was also delicious.

photos.caption: Photo of Eleven - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Peanut butter dessert.  Delicious.
Photo of Eleven - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Swordfish with mussels and grilled calamari.  Very good.

_Iitn0VTcbgV-QM0wPqLRw.text: Wowser what a bummer. My husband and I came here for happy hour a few weeks ago for our anniversary. The game plan was to sit in the bar, have a couple snacks, then get a table and enjoy dinner in the dining room. Didnt exactly work out that way though.    We arrived about a half hour before happy hour was over. The hostess notified us that it was first come first serve.  Thats fine we make our way into the bar. It is pretty busy but there is a high-top table in the middle of the bar area but no chairs. We look around for some empty chairs. To the left is a table of woman with 3 empty chairs. We ask the ladies if we could use them and they said that they are saving them. Go to the table of businessmen to the right with 2 empty chairs. Same response . So now here we are. Stuck eating standing up. My problem with this is that it is first come first serve. We are paying customers that want to SIT and spend money. The chairs being hoarded arnt making anyone any money. There shouldve been a manager or server keeping an eye on this. Eventually after our food came out, a table got up and we ran over ourselves and took two chairs. Moving on.    Our server seemed terrified and overwelmed. We never got his name. Or really anything about him. He came over about ten minutes after sitting (err... standing) at the table. Grabbed our drink order. Came back about 8 minutes later with two wines. Took our order and wasn't to be seen again until we were ready for our check. He was obviously very busy but maybe someone should have been helping him.    Onto the food. We got the brussels, calamari, shishito peppers, and oysters. All off of the happy hour menu. Due to allergies I could not try to oysters but they were good for the price according to my husband. However the remaining 3 dishes were almost inedible due to the amount of salt in all of the dishes. I am a salt lover but holy moly. We kind of picked over them, notified the server when we asked for our bill and decided not to stay for dinner.    Now I understand this is a long yelp review but I was pretty dissapointed. And yes, we shouldve brought up our concerns while we were dining. Between the hostage chairs, food quality and service it was a let-down. I understand we were happy hour customers. Not dinner customers. But should recieve the same quality food and service that would be recieved in the dining room. We may try Eleven eventually again down the road.

C1GiquQWc5pNSDBpHrloKA.text: I have been here several times, most recently for Sunday brunch. Each time, the service is fast, friendly and spot on with their food and beverage recs (both wine and cocktails). Ambience is modern and although they can seat many people, it doesn't feel crowded because of the way the space is divided (outdoor patio, bar area with TVs, upstairs with two separate sections). Sunday brunch was excellent with their prix fixe menu. All around, a huge fan of this restaurant!

rhhXdRyG7so6TmXJEdqmMg.text: I always enjoy Eleven for dinner, great drinks, meals and service. Never disappoints but some may find it pricey to enjoy on a regular basis.  A great value is Eleven's Sunday brunch! For $29 you get a choice of cocktail or juice. The Cucumber Moscow Mule was so fresh and yummy! Choice of appetizer...from six fresh oysters to beignets something tasty for everyone and then an entree ranging from waffles, burgers, omelettes with bacon and so much more. All served with quality sides and attentive service. (Peet's coffee is so tasty too!) What a value! A great place to take visitors or just yourself. I have gone several times and like to keep Eleven's brunch in heavy rotation

KgwaSTOglte7rP415hzlLw.text: Be prepared for some of the most condescending hosts you will ever meet! My husband and I had a reservation at 7/23 at 8:45 pm and we checked in at 8:40 pm. The host told us (without welcoming us and without eye contact) that our table was not yet ready but we can wait at the bar and then check in again. My husband and I made our way to the bar before we realized the host had told us to check in again and did not mention that he would come get us. Don't most restaurants have the host come find you at the bar once your table is ready?   So we made our way back to the host desk to make sure we didn't misunderstood the "check-in again" instruction.  The host looked down his nose , which incidentally had a bat in the right cave, and enunciated, "As I have MENTIONED you will NEED to CHECK IN again... in FIFTEEN minutes, which is when YOU made YOUR reservation for." In fifteen minutes? That means 9 pm! We informed the host again that we had a 8:45 pm reservation. The host checked his computer, asked for our last name again, and said our table will be ready in a few minutes. He did not apologize for confusing our reservation and he did not apologize for the delay. In a few minutes, his colleague led us to our table without a single word of welcome. After handing our menus with a stiff and very sarcastic gentle incline at the waist, he left without a single word wishing us a pleasant evening or meal. Meanwhile, the hosts seemed to be very kind and warm to the other patrons who were white. Needless to say, my husband and I are not white.  The hosts really ruined the experience for us. We contemplated walking out but our waiter arrived and his charm and welcoming attitude convinced us to give the food a chance.  The food was delicious but not worth being mistreated for. If it was not for the nasty, condescending, and possibly racist attitude of the hosts, I would give this restaurant a 4-star review.   I hope the restaurant management considers retraining their hosts to be more welcoming and hospitable. After all, the restaurant business is a a business of hospitality and service.

SVgEVnsIrXeCafel-l4ubg.text: One of my favorite restaraunt a in Pittsburgh. I've gotten the chefs tasting menu at least 5 different times and thoroughly enjoyed it each time. Good cocktails and wine list, thought the markup in the wine is in the high side. Good pastry effort. Even better execution by the line cooks. This a great place for a nice date.

XECKDfhll9p8c_cNv7cCDQ.text: One word: OUTSTANDING! We enjoyed the brunch prix fix menu; 1. Bloody Mary, grilled sticky (cinnamon roll with bacon/butter sauce), and smoked lamb huevos ranchero with goat cheese and salsa verde. 2. Bloody Mary, pastrami hash with poached farm egg, eggs Benedict with prosciutto copa and house made English muffin. Quite possibly the best eggs Benedict I've ever had! The muffin was delicious and the egg was perfectly poached: the soft, creamy yolk stayed completely intact after being pierced. The arugula/pink grapefruit salad was the perfect foil for the richly decadent hollandaise and prosciutto. The service was excellent; knowledgeable and readily available but not over-bearing. BRAVO, ELEVEN!

nWgURybyhSLpLF3bFo6_2g.text: This place was fantastic and is great for a power lunch or upscale (but not stuffy) dinner.  I had the chicken sandwich wrapped in prosciutto for lunch and it was delicious (with a little kick to it as well).  The service was great.   Definitely worth checking out.

UIAkPUPxE5F4XPeI4568jg.text: We came here for a pre-show dinner.  The different breads were probably my favorite part--not just Italian, but different sweet breads too.  I felt that the waiters were trained to be a little pretentious--frequently saying "pardon my reach."  Otherwise, good food, and they got us to our show on time.

0-1ef-Vv3RgnWHjxvDiGJg.text: I recently went for the Valentine's Day dinner tasting. I did the vegetarian tasting while my husband did the regular tasting. All dishes for both of us were average. Nothing wow. Service was very attentive. Beautiful ambience. Great wine/drink selection. Other than that, nothing blew me away.   My recent dinner at Luma in Mt. Lebanon was light years better and half the price ($85 vs. $200, not that I have any problem at all dropping a pretty penny on a meal). I've been to almost every restaurant on Pittsburgh Magazine's "Top 25 Restaurants" list for 2012. I'm sure it made the list for a reason, I just didn't see it. I might try going back again to try something other than a tasting, but not before I explore some other restaurants I have on my short list.

wn9DW1nLMVCHyLXDX8qwVw.text: Tried this place for the foie gras appetizer. It was good, but not the best ever. It was slightly over cooked. I had the beef tenderloin with bone marrow for my entree. It was cooked perfectly and the marrow was a nice compliment. We had drinks at the bar before dinner- the Eleven Mule was perfect! Ginger beer is house made. The ambiance is my favorite part of this restaurant.

jK6afDTDl3ZseGQ5-k1y6g.text: Overall a good experience, just not great one !  The welcome was good. Although the restaurant was completely empty, my favorite time to come, because it really seperates the service from the experience.   I sat at the bar between 3-5pm on a Monday. I was the only guest in the restaurant (btw). Not one single chef or manager said a word to me even though I faced, eye-to-eye, three of them (this is just sad). I greeted my bartender, whom was also my greeter when I walked through the front doors with no one in sight and meandered towards the bar.   I was welcomed traditionally with a drink menu and I explained how I had a Birthday coupon for an entree, that I'd either use it here or down the road at Kaya. The bartender was friendly and offered the food choices and explained the boundaries of the coupon.  The free entree coupon is spot on and amazing - kudos to the purveyors of BigBurrito, a solid and friendly idea for a local chain. My only complaint would be to instruct staff as to how to act for someone's birthday; although, not special to some people it is special to others and in the Sevice Industry making a big deal is seen as par for the course, especially of a guest brings the event to attention. Support the great and awesome promotion with equally high expectations of your personnel).  I ordered a gin drink and then changed it, the bartender adjusted without insult and made a fine Hendrix Martini with cucumber garnish (however, as with any garnish - less is more). It was tasty and I loved it.   I ordered the suggestion: burger, MR with cheese, and I made conversation about the business, atmosphere, etc. Although there was no one else at all in the entire building whom was a guest, the bartender seemed a tad rushed, as if there were more important things to do. I often employ a trick to see how good service can be, a trick which has failed me three times in Pittsburgh and one I think I'll save for other cities - it did not work here either.   Being new to town I did expect a good meal (thus all the talk is about only a few restaurants here worth trying). A good meal I received. The burger was cooked as I ordered and the accoutrements were perfect. The fries were tasty as well. I shared the meal with a glass of Grenache. I recommend it - light, and splendid for a burger and fries.   Unfortunately this is where the 100% tip took a back seat. My bartender disappeared only to return once, as I was barley invested in my meal, to inquire on it's flavor and my state of joy. A young man appeared, not much personality, and after taking up and enjoying the earlier bartender's company I was merely a paying toll member of a food truck line, and to beat the band it was my birthday, I displayed the evidence with ID and coupon, yet I was treated nominally in a restaurant with three guests.   It's what I always say keeps good restaurants from being great restaurants: Service.   I enjoyed my late lunch and birthday wine. I enjoyed the ambiance (I love quiet and classy, and for the brief moment I was there, this was it). I enjoyed the meal. Everyone loves a free entree. What I take points away for is the service: friendly yet vacant; helpful yet struggling; somewhat compassionate but not completely professional and what it lacks it completely fails in charm - a complete lack of charm.   I often dress down for uppity places and up for low style juke joints (throws managers off the scent). It's an even tell-tale sign of the level of service and te steps one takes to achieve success (20% or better).   One of my biggest pet peeves so far in Pittsburgh is the lack of consistency. The service part of the "service" industry has yet to take hold in the few places I've been.   Here's to proving me wrong on my next visit with Big Burrito. Thanks for the meal.  Thanks for the times. Overall I rate Eleven a C+, until next time.  Service after all is only outdone by flavor of the meal. And a meal is only as good as the service.

nL_Yb9NSWzeLJIYnpPYKaQ.text: Food was good but server threw a tantrum when he saw our 18% tip.

l1cL9SMeWk78K4JFqh6ttg.text: OK! The pork chop was good, however it was overpriced at $31. The ambiance was nice, however it seemed like we were being rushed from the second we walked in the door even though there were plenty of open tables on a Tuesday night. It seems like the staff is living off of their press clippings rather than their actions today.

2NveTkZ-Jy5JhZR7-M470w.text: This place is a little pricey but so awesome for special occasions - a little tip - if you sign up at bigburrito.com you'll get a postcard to get a free dinner entree on your birthday week to use at any of the big burrito restaurants - this one is worth it! They have a huge wine list to choose from and they print their dinner menu daily with special seasonal dishes. Hubby always gets the lamb chops or lamb loins (both he loves) and I like to try different dishes when I go. This time they had a seafood tasting which included a crab cake, scallop and striped bass all with white grits and some veggies- very good but I probably wouldn't get again. Oh wait- I forgot to mention the Ricotta Cavatelli appetizer we got - it's brussels sprouts, roasted butternut squash, serrano chilies, golden raisins, goat cheese, toasted bread crumbs and whoa! It is lick your plate clean delicious! Do yourself a favor and get this!!! Get dressed up and come here for a fancy, grown up, good time with delicious, grown up, good food.

cFjJ5BJE71iC6HvIgZaTsQ.text: Great service the waiter and all of the bidders were very attentive. They treated us wonderfully!

_97Lt_Vvml-Xf720wPfTYw.text: We stopped after the home show for an early dinner. I jab the potato bacon soup which was delicious. I also had the lobster roll that was loaded with lobster and the brioche roll toasted perfectly. My wife had the hanger steak and fries. She said it was delicious. The waitress Taylor was an excellent server. She was very nice and made our visit enjoyable.

A2Nz3Z-wQYDba4aTzJDTKw.text: So I only went to their Sunday brunch and I cannot vouch for dinner, but I must say their brunch was AMAZING.  First of all, for an app, entree, and brunch cocktail for only $30 it's an excellent deal. And everything we tried was absolutely amazing. I started with the beignets which had a banana and rum sauce and walnuts on top. I have never tasted anything more delicious. For my entree I stuck with the eggs benedict. It was a very good eggs benedict but I would definitely like to go back and be more adventurous and try something else off of the menu (which seems like it changes quite frequently). I got the red sangria for my brunch cocktail and it was delicious as well. I have absolutely no complaints to make about Eleven. The service was great, the ambience was great, the food was great, the price was great. And I have finally found the perfect brunch to impress all of my out of town guests with.

bIaVpDKQDA5Iz3o1PSzFrg.text: Not bad. Sat at the bar. Had the Hangar steak. Had way too much marinade and the rest was bland. Wine was good but way too much for the food that was served. Waitress was nice and did not really care if we were happy with food. May not go back.

WIL46obSLi4NcQz66IJ0JQ.text: Great dinner, and excellent wines by the glass. Service was terrific. The pork chop was presented in an interesting way, precut. I requested extra veggies and they brought out a nice size additional serving, exactly what I was looking for. I have dined at Eleven a number of times in the past. This was their best showing. I look forward to my next visit.

vzSSALep3cVH0IxvWN6iKg.text: Eleven has a really nice happy hour special and I enjoy coming here for oysters. The restaurant is enormous and offers many types of dining experiences (there is the upscale dining area upstairs, the casual bar, and the intimate patio outside). I like to dine in the patio and look out at the industrial buildings of the Strip District.  This is a great place to visit for an intimate dinner in Pittsburgh. I also recommend getting a bottle of wine from their  comprehensive selection!

6O4Ow_kWCU742NzTDYmg6Q.text: Eleven is the 5* Pittsburgh restaurant. Dinner tonight, as always, was as good as it gets. We chose the salmon, lobster tail and tortellini from the tasting menu, and banana cream pie. Can't ask for more.

-3qz4a0yEmO9lGrKXdo3bw.text: This restaurant has been on our list for a little while as it is part of the Big Burrito Group. My husband and I took my mother-in-law for her birthday for brunch to try something unique. I was intrigued with the idea of paying a flat rate for the meal and having a few courses in return. A concept I have read about, but have not partaken in.  We arrived close the end of the brunch and I thought for sure we may not be given a table. To my surprise, we were ushered into the Tavern side of the building and we could choose our own seat. I loved the atmosphere -  slightly romantic, however the use of the old garage doors was superb. Sunday afternoon football was displayed on the televisions behind the magnificent bar which was nice. My only complaint was that due to so many windows on the exterior of the building, the restaurant was quite chilly.   A young man greeted us and explained the ordering process. I ended up selecting Coconut and Sunflower Seed Granola for an appetizer, and a Prosciutto Cotto, Caramalized Onions, and Cheddar Omelet with a side of orange juice (we could have opted for cocktails that was included in the price but went for the juices instead). What I loved about this place is everything is FRESH! Instantly, I knew that the orange juice was freshly squeezed. Prior to receiving our meals, we were served a basket with an array of baked goods - crossiants, blueberry muffins, cornbread, and biscuits - all fresh and made on site with a side of raspberry jam and honey butter, also made at the restaurant. I was thoroughly impressed with all of the food. My omelet came with a freshly made sausage patty that was close to being the star of my meal. Everything was delicious and I would not hesitate to return here for a special occasion.   Overall, this was a wonderful experience. My husband and mother-in-law enjoyed their food and juices almost as much as I did. We did not leave hungry. The price for the brunch was fair considering the amount of food we were served. Our waiter was very nice, slow at getting us our check and returning it to us, but nonetheless, he knew his stuff and was very pleasant. The prices meals other than the brunch seem expensive but if everything is as fresh and well presented as it was for brunch, it might be worth a try.

Photo of Eleven - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Coconut and Sunflower Seed Granola

C_Vf-t81RG4zpnIdCGnMhQ.text: We went to Eleven for lunch and had a very delicious meal, which I would highly recommend to anyone visiting or residing in Pittsburgh. The meal was worth every penny.  We started our meal with the Barrel & Solera Aged Manhattan and Fall Collins. There is nothing bad to say about either drink, and the cranberry in the collins leant a very nice tartness to the drink.  Moving on we shared the Spicy Tuna Tartare that included sambal, avocado, pea tendrils, and papadum (Indian crispy cracker). While the tuna tartare was a bit spicy the rest of the ingredients balanced out the heat quite well. The pea tendrils really shone through even as a garnish.  The highlight of the meal was definitely the main entrees. The Gerber Farms Chicken featured a roasted chicken breast, braised leg risotto, Swiss chard (and with some other greens), and thyme jus. This entree was rich and full of flavor, but by the end I felt overwhelmed with the saltiness of the dish. The risotto and chicken were expertly cooked and so full of flavor and textures.   I had a small bite of the Sea Scallops, and again full of flavor cooked so nicely. It's really hard to find a good sea scallop that tastes good, and is perfectly cooked.

Neither of us really enjoyed our steak, and the taste of the potato coquette reminded me of sushi somehow.   The Candy Bar dessert almost made up for how disappointing dinner was - highly recommend it. Waiter was attentive, atmosphere was nice, but highly unlikely we will go back or recommend to others.

70UHcWD8Zijh2IwoXrp9tA.text: A very good higher end restaurant. We went for my girlfriend's birthday and they treated her very well. Our waiter was fantastic. My girlfriend had the halibut and enjoyed every bite, cleaning her entire plate. I had the hangar steak, it was okay, but I didn't care much for the sides, to me, they were a bit over seasoned and the rosemary overpowered any other tastes. That being said, we really did enjoy our evening out and will return.

4kQtouaE2FMS9tIkOjFuoQ.text: My wife, mother, and I all went visited here for brunch on a Sunday afternoon.  We arrived around 1:30, just before brunch ended. This is definitely one of the fancier places I have visited for brunch.  The building still retains some of its industrial roots with a nice modern, classy, and warm atmosphere.    The brunch special here includes juice or cocktail, appetizer, and main entree.  I ended up ordering pineapple juice (lame, should have been more fun and ordered a cocktail), the ricotta squash crepe, and the lamb huevos rancheros.  The meal started out by bringing out a variety of baked goods along with some blackberry jam and honey butter.  It was evident everything here is homemade, and when we questioned our waiter he informed us that the restaurant had its own bakery!  Very impressive and very well done on such a small and simple beginning to our meal.  The ricotta squash while visibly impressive I thought lacked a little flavor. There was no dominate flavor that really shined in the dish.  Lastly, the much anticipated huevos rancheros.  I had been craving this meal for a while, and although this isn't your typical huevos rancheros, it was still excellent! The combination of lamb, goat cheese, egg, and a chip base to the dish all did wonders in my mouth.  The texture was pleasing as well as the flavor.    My wife and mother enjoyed their meals as well. Next time I must try the eleven burger. I have heard from more than one person that this is the best burger in Pittsburgh.  The price here is a little higher than what I typically spend, but the food for sure is worth it if you're looking for a nice place for brunch! I will have to try a brunch cocktail next time I come as well.  This was a great experience here and I strongly recommend this place if you're looking for a nicer place to eat.

r3NLRhzuKFdFiQQQITMoiQ.text: Food was on point. Server was very sweet. Was a little disappointed with the taste of my cocktail but everything else was good. Definitely recommended.

Sm0cw6G0xATLA4IPgtsP5Q.text: Best place I have eaten in PGH. Could write a long dissertation.....but just go!!!Great happy hour specials if on a budget, staff is very friendly and helpful. If you like them the barrel aged Manhattan...WOW!!! Bourbon is Makers...a steal at $13.

WKegeypZ212ycbsfoeLX3g.text: Comfortable and relaxing tavern atmosphere.  Pricy food but good.  It's all fresh made but portions are small if you are hungry.  The potatoes and curds was the most filling part of the meal.  The oysters are small but very fresh and the house made sauces are great.  The nettle pasta is very good and my favorite part of the meal as taste.  The candy bar dessert was plated beautifully but in the salty side with no unique pallet quality.  It's like a salty Reese's cup.  Service was great!
