7Ire8IsXks8iryGDHNpo4Q.text: I was in town for a customer visit and wanted to wow the .  I asked the customers where they wanted to go and they unanimously said 11 because they've never been able to go.  We called and with some good luck, they were able to get our larger group in at a reasonable time!  We sat upstairs and completely enjoyed the experience.  Without a doubt, I had the best strip steak I've ever had.  Hands down phenomenal!  Damn it's good!  I still talk about it.  Excellent oysters to boot. Great customer service, great food, great atmosphere! Don't hesitate, Go!

t0KTA7zJoCjTrXc9eQzKEg.text: In my opinion, this is the best restaurant in Pittsburgh.  The atmosphere is romantic and refined, yet seems to be casual at the same time.  The lamb tacos are to die for and the seasonal desert is always heaven.  As far as entrees are concerned, I like the chicken and the fish.  The service is nothing short of spectacular and the wine list is extensive.  While i prefer to eat in the main dining area, the bar area is nice for a very casual (i.e., jeans and heels) kind of night.

na2R7pjgQOjtbzpjeStGyg.text: Apparently Eleven is the place to be in Pittsburgh.  Not only were we graced with the presence of Ben Roethlisberger (see: Pittsburgh Steelers) sitting around the corner from us, but Taylor Lautner (see:  Twilight) joined him soon after.  We had a pretty good time gawking at them until Lautner's body guard accused us of trying to take pictures of him (as if!) and they closed the curtain on the private room.  Anyway!  This place is desperately trying to be NYC style, and doing a pretty good job of it.  The decor is schnazzy and the big booths are cozy for a group.  The service was wonderful.. very attentive and accomodating.  The menu was sprinkled with the names of farms where the produce and meat come from.  The food was pretty good, but nothing memorable.  And the prices were definitely NYC - entrees anywhere from $23 to $55.  For Pittsburgh, this place deserves four stars.  Don't get me wrong, I love PIttsburgh, but it's just not really a haven for fancy food (see: Primanti Brothers).  I'd recommend it for a nice night out on the town.  Who knows, you may be even sitting next to Roethlisberger himself...

BsJQOUPmxw4mKH8Dfkye3g.text: Excellent birthday meal! We were impressed with their ability to make a reservation for a Thursday night the day of. The atmosphere was very sophisticated/modern and there is ample space between tables to feel that your meal is private and you are not crammed against someone else. They brought out fresh bread which was delicious. My partner and I shared the seafood tasting and gnocchi dishes, but which were a decent portion and absolutely delicious. All the seafood was cooked perfectly. For dessert I selected an in season sorbet, which was served with fresh berries and cookies. The sorbet had outstanding strong flavor and was an excellent option for a lighter, but flavorful dessert. The menu is a bit pricey, but seemed comparable to other nice restaurants with similar quality of food. This would be an excellent place for both social and business meals and we will definitely return.

bCvoEZ8w1Em9iE0KN059FQ.text: Now Pittsburgh is not exactly culinary nirvana. There are people who put fries in their salad. Atrocious!  Eleven is consistently good and one of the few standouts. The ambience is nice, but it is a big place that can get lively. Food tastes good, quality is ok, portion sizes are not too big. One meal I remember in particular, when they touched culinary greatness. Otherwise, solid food but 'fancy' for the Burgh.

sRFMfD_PlS-h3UJbZfOYbA.text: Absolutely perfect experience. We shared the tartare which was split on two plates for us to eat. I had the pork chop, as I have a fish allergy my dining experiences are limited, but it was prepared exceptionally. We also had the chocolate cake that had small slices of crispy chocolate that was awesome. Our server was accommodating and polite as we wanted privacy and he was diligent enough to give us just the right amount of attention. He knew his wine pairings and recommended something both my date and I (who have very different preferences) could enjoy. The cocktails were very good, I had the sangria and my date a manhattan, (yes, on top of a bottle of wine). The bread was very fancy and delectable. I definitely look forward to coming back.

oVRh0CxXkiOuHKSegC8hLQ.text: My fiance and I went here before an opera performance. We were very pleasantly surprised at the decor- urban chic, plenty of room for intimate dinners or for groups.  Upstairs bar was very cool.   We were seated immediately (we made reservations early on a Friday night).  Our waiter asked us if we were going to a show so that he could make sure we were served and out in plenty of time to get to our venue.  The food was not the usual run-of-the-mill fare, and we very much enjoyed our meals.

koA-fyw_yNheKY7AxWfs2g.text: Being a vegetarian, brunches can be pretty monotonous. Visiting Eleven for brunch last week was such a welcome relief. I opted for the pre fix menu and the dishes were just awesome. The gnocchi was rich and flavorful. I called for Ruby Red and the cocktail was a-mazing! The ambience is classy and its a great way to spend your weekend morning. I called for the cheese appetizer and they had a great variety. Would certainly go back!

7NIpSAyW6Fj2DSS_F-yJfA.text: Three years ago, I moved to Pittsburgh and my friend took me to this nice restaurant for lunch to prove to me that Pittsburgh wasn't that bad. Since then it became ofne of my favorite fine dining places in Pittsburgh. The food was really delicious and I could tell that the chef was an extremely talented chef! The service was outstanding, and the atmosphere was pretty cool and not too formal.

1GLXEzJUHQ13-og9zkG9lA.text: The food is overpriced and average at best; however the waiters and hostesses were nice.   The main deterrence is really aspects of the Management team that run the place, specifically Ron, who was rude and displayed inappropriate behavior to our group when approached. We had an issue with our reservation which happens time-to-time, but when asked nicely for some changes, no one would accommodate. I understand not having the room to accommodate which is fine but there is no reason to be rude and aggressive when communicating this information back to the customers. The GM handled the situation and was apologetic but I would not go back based on my experience.   Regards,

KYQVE5I-E7E_lrO0aAXG4Q.text: Great experience tonight at eleven. Make sure to have reservations!  Excellent food and great service. Loved the sashimi and beef tenderloin, great recommendations from the wait staff! Beautiful atmosphere, Just wish more wine selections by the glass.

_MlNd6179HHNlN1jsjZBJA.text: Perfect Service & Perfect Food. Whenever I get my Big Burrito free meal for my birthday card in the mail, this is where I go!   I've never had bad food here or bad service. Really top notch.

uWfZ_sBS9rv-qWhc82hVPQ.text: I've been here twice now, and the food is consistently very good (though not daring enough to be called great) and the service really quite good. If you're looking for a nice dinner out in Pittsburgh, this place is a good bet. My only complaint would be that if you're going for a quiet dinner and they put you upstairs above the bar, it's like you're in the bar--it's too loud.

f77L6opLwV_lP8gK0I-iog.text: Average at best.  Food was super salty!  Every dish was so covered in it.  Drinks were unique and tasty.  Service was below average.  I had to send back the raw lamb app, smelled terrible.

dqBbJ6NX1Ptub9UdaLX1TA.text: Ducked in here for a drink on the way home after dinner.  Cool atmosphere.  Good bartender.  Ordered a Booker's bourbon.  Asked for one with one ice cube.  I don't like it with a lot of ice because it dilutes the bourbon but it's 126 proof and that's a bit much for August.  So. I compromise and go with one cube.  The bartender asked if I wanted a small or large cube.  I call that good service.  Of course he may have been pulling a prank on me.  "I just asked this dude if he wanted a small or large one and he said he wanted a large one.  Ha! Ha! Ha!

E7JHrTX8EudYHPAnoZBJeA.text: When I first went to Eleven years ago, I would have given the restaurant 5 stars. When I went today, however, I felt let down. For my husband's and my appetizers, the waiters brought out tuna tartare rather than the steak tartare that we had ordered, and the lobster risotto had a 1.5-inch piece of shell in it. One waiter looked nervous and acted as if he were working his first-ever shift. He was teamed with another waiter who looked more experienced and apologized for the incorrect appetizer. For my main entree, I ordered the seafood tasting. Its salmon filet was a decent size. The crab cake had much meat in it but was a bit spicy and dry. My one scallop was tasty. I liked the baby kale. I was not a fan of the trumpet royale mushrooms, which were hard to cut and chew. My husband's strip steak was cooked the way that he wanted. Its accompanying parmesan tots were high-quality tater tots. For dessert we enjoyed an upside-down pineapple cake. Based on the two appetizers that were messed up, the entrees that tasted good but did not blow us away, and the waiters' awkward service, I am unsure if I will return again soon.

dKuqTk8vIe2Qdw-FLk-m3w.text: Eleven is a fine upscale restaurant with a lively, engaging atmosphere, adventurous and interesting dishes, and a large selection of wine, beer, and cocktails.  My wife and I were visiting from Cincinnati, and enjoy an upscale restaurant now and then. Reading the reviews on Eleven drew us to it. We were surprised and delighted when we were able to get a 7:30 reservation for Saturday night that very afternoon. I appreciated that we could reserve through Open Table right on the Yelp app. Very easy. We arrived about 30 minutes early, ready to get a cocktail, but they were able to seat us immediately. Once we walked in, it was clear why we were so readily able to get seating: this is a large restaurant! For this type of restaurant, I am used to smaller, more crowded rooms. This appears to be in a converted factory or warehouse, and the large main room with high cielings, exposed rafters, and contemporary decor and furnishings was fun and comfortable. The wine storage room hovers above, encased in glass, calling to you to try its selections.  We were seated next to an open kitchen, which was boistrous but not noisy. The guest is brought into the open kitchen experience on purpose - this was not bad seating. We rather enjoyed seeing the action and feeling the bustle.  The service was competent but did not rise to the level of the food. We were not ready to order cocktails when our server first visited (my wife was not sure she was ready to try a cocktail with frothed egg white). After a second quick check, we decided on our cocktail order, but the server did not return for about ten minutes. Once we ordered the cocktail and some oysters, we were given only a few minutes before we were asked for our orders. I was expecting some explanation of featured dishes or recommendations, but our server got straight to business - maybe that's just how it's done at Eleven, or how it's done in Pittsburgh, but the pace was a little fast for the evening-long experience we were prepared for. We decided on the chef's tasting menu with wine pairings. The dishes were brought out at a somewhat irregular pace, but all were served at the appropriate temperature, and all of the service was absolutely courteous. There is the matter of the bread service - at unpredictable intervals, a woman came by to offer us bread. Once, after our appetizers (about 20 minutes after we were seated), again about 10 minutes later, and again when we had our dessert. Good bread, but a strange serving style.  We chose a plate of four oysters to start, two for each. Two were of average size, and two were unexpectedly small. They were excellent with the hot sauce.  The Chef's tasting menu was excellent - tuna tartare, grilled swordfish with couscous, sun-dried tomatoes, and pickled jalepano slices, lamb, and a fantastic selection of desserts. Despite the dessert listed with the tasting menu, we were presented with the opportunity to select any of the desserts, and our wine would be paired appropriately. The paired wine selections were very well chosen. These were wines I would have never chosen on my own, but the pairing with the dishes made them a unique experience. Mind that the paired wine selections were half-size pours. This is entirely appropriate for pairings with a multiple course meal, but don't expect to get four glasses of wine.  In conclusion, a fine atmosphere, outstanding food, and competent service. Considering the overall experience, Eleven does not entirely justify the prices it charges, but it's close. For the price, I would expect a higher class of service, atmosphere, or more adventurous dishes. It is absolutely worth a visit.

7b2FVO_wM98J6wS2WdVE-g.text: I was so excited to go back to Eleven. I was there last fall for a business lunch and it was amazing, I couldn't wait to try dinner. Now that dinner is over, I am feeling a little let down. For the price you pay, I expected better. It was a bunch of little issues. My husband's fork was dirty, their was sediment in his wine, the tables were a little cramped. The food was good, just good. When you are paying $36 and $42 for your entrees you kind of expect them to be amazing. I had the Seafood Tasting. It consisted of what was probably a 3 ounce crab cake, a 3 ounce piece of salmon, one tiny scallop and a couple of sliced trumpet mushrooms, no starch. I had hoped for maybe risotto or roasted potatoes with it. My husband's lamb was good, but for $42, he expected more than two small chops. We also had to listen to the woman at the table next to us complain about her steak for nearly the entire evening. But I had to agree with her, if you are paying $52 for a steak, it better be epic. For two starters, two cocktails, entrees and two glasses of wine, we paid $180 including tip. Unfortunately, I can't say it was worth it.

VKnzRVwEJz-yio8yf5QhUw.text: Yelp, why have you lead me so far astray?   Although we were treated with enthusiastic service, our food was generally boring with few, if any, of the dishes standing out. (The desserts were good, but I'm not sure how you come up with bland desserts.)  I had the chef's tasting menu. My co-diner had the vegetarian version. We left disappointed... as time has gone on the disappointment has turned to depression as I wish I had all that cash back.   Nothing was terrible, but the quality did not match the price.

8_g1pMTu6tAqa9Ia9tzpHA.text: I feel bored by the idea of writing this, even as I'm starting the review...I wanted to like Eleven, and technically enjoyed it, but it all somehow seemed expected. I'm trying to be thorough about my Pittsburgh food experiences, though, so here goes.  I've been here three times, and each time was slightly less interesting than the one before.  The food averaged to the same quality, but I had expected more creativity and change over time, especially for such a high price.  The food ranges from average to very good, but rarely tops out at excellent (I say this having tried the chef's tasting). I do recommend it, but only because Pittsburgh is sorely lacking in the romantic food date genre.  Docked two stars because the quality is inconsistent, and it's definitely overpriced.

HWZhDWKeyMQthzZXyW31Bg.text: I'm eating dinner at Eleven as I write this, and I have to say that it is one of the best meals I've had in Pittsburgh.  I had the tasting menu with wine pairing, and the wines were well matched with the food.  Everything was pretty solid, including the service, but I actually felt that they were too attentive.  They weren't extremely busy, and one of their many servers would approach the table every few minutes.  I found this a little awkward, since I was alone and just wanted to eat, although other people might appreciate the personal attention.  Also, the place has some bizarre, concept, surrealistic erotic prints hanging on the walls and is going for the "East Berlin Hotel Lobby" decor, so I kind of felt like I was in one of those Mike Myers "Deitur" Saturday Night Live skits from the 1990s ("Would you like to touch my monkey?")  The best item on the tasting menu by far was the dessert, although the paired dessert wine tasted like straight-up grape juice.  The plates were very seafood-heavy, and they love radishes, the menu is scattered with radish dishes, which is interesting.  I've never been a big fan of the radish, but they don't seem to get used much, so it's a nice try.  The presentation of the food was really good, but I was left a little unimpressed by the flavor.  It's expensive for Pittsburgh, even more than I thought it would be going in.  Overall, though, the wine pairing was reasonable, getting four and a half glasses for $35, when they are charging about $10 for most of their glasses.  If it were a little cheaper, this would definitely be a four-star place.

SG1SK_Nn9bnLWTSnEXDnhg.text: First review! Let me preface this review by saying that I do not typically criticize restaurants, but Eleven was definitely a bit of a let-down for how highly rated it seems. After all, though my dining companion and I came later on a Monday night, the dining room seemed busy and remained full for much of our time here.  Our experience at Eleven definitely took off to a promising start. The hostess allowed us to book the Chef's Table for two, even though it typically is intended to seat 4-6 people. While it did not give us a particular insightful view of the kitchen, it was definitely offset in a nice cozy alcove with plenty of space to accommodate our voracious appetites!   Unfortunately, our server was not especially friendly or enthusiastic, so we did not get much advice for the appetizers we decided to order before venturing to the Chef's Tasting.  Half-Dozen Oysters | Not too shabby. We were not given any details about the origin of these oysters, so I can only comment that the ELEVEN hot sauce was a very spicy version of cocktail sauce!  Seared Scallops | The scallops themselves had a nice consistency, if a bit rubbery, but they sat on a strange stew of peas and ham that I did not especially enjoy. The heartiness of the flavor seemed to overwhelm the typical delicacy of seared scallops and we left much of it on the plate.  Chef's Tasting Course #1: Seared Hudson Valley Foie Gras | Since California's ban on foie gras, I have not had it nearly as often, so I was really looking forward to this appetizer. Yet, though I can normally be convinced to love seared foie gras dish at any price point, I can honestly say that this is one of the worst preparations I have ever tasted. The foie gras itself was far too well-done; of my admitted generous portion, only the very center had the soft, buttery consistency that defines the dish, while the outer portions were a little too much like...liver. It also sat on a strangely incongruent piece of rough breading that added little to the melding of flavors, but our server did not seem to appreciate my asking about what it had been. (Turns out--carrot cake!)  Chef's Tasting Course #2: Seared Salmon | While both my dining companion and I usually enjoy salmon in any form, this "seared" salmon had a nearly fried crisp that masked its usual flavor. This dish's saving grace was its bedding of rich polenta that paired surprisingly well with the stark vinegary greens on the side. It was paired rather oddly with a Pinot Noir.  Chef's Tasting Course #3: Jubilee Hilltop Ranch Strip Steak | When our server presented us this grass-fed steak and--exact words--"tater tots," we probably should not have expected too much from this simultaneously rare and stringy cut of meat. The tater tots far outshone the meat itself. Less said the better.  Yellowtail Sashimi | My dining companion was so unimpressed by the steak from the third course that he did not finish it. We did not want to create problems by sending it back, but we added an order for the yellowtail sashimi appetizer to close our meal on a better note. The three slices of slightly fishy yellowtail atop cucumber salad was definitely not the worst nouveau-sauced sashimi either of us have ever had, but again, it was not especially amazing either.  Tasting Menu Dessert for Her: Flourless Chocolate Cake with Bourbon Ice Cream | This dense, rich mass of chocolate was both well presented and delicious! :) Kudos to the pastry chef on this one.  Tasting Menu Dessert for Him: Brown Butter Ice Cream Sandwiches | My dining companion adores ice cream sandwiches, so he may have been a little biased, but I can agree that the combination of oatmeal raisin cookies, cold ice cream, and graham crumbles was indeed magical. Plus, the kitchen did remember to include a piece of chocolate with a message that I had called in earlier--so bonus points there.  Ambitious Dessert to Share: Creme Fraiche Brulee | At the end of the meal, we both commented that dessert was by far the highlight--so much so that we had to try our luck at another. The creme brulee and accompanying jelly macaron were both good but not wonderful. Perhaps another ice cream sandwich might have been better!  Ultimately, the Chef's Tasting Menu & Wine Pairing, while delicious in theory and in description, did not exhibit much innovation or character. We enjoyed elements of each course, but none of them stood out as being particularly memorable. Of the five wines we sampled between the two of us, only the first (2011 Semillon) seemed worth an individual order.  Had our service been more consistent or friendly, I would have been tempted to rate our dinner a 3.5 or 4; however, for how much we were both looking forward to our fine dining experience at Eleven, we just felt underwhelmed at every turn. Maybe we came on an off-night, or perhaps we are just spoiled by LA dining, but I would definitely not make Eleven a priority on future trips to Pittsburgh!

NpUTx99APkgrbhIvYn1EXg.text: Eleven is one of those places we frequent for happy hour on the way home from work. We've tried nearly everything on the happy hour food menu (updated on a fairly regular basis) and I've been a big fan of everything. Currently, the shishito peppers are a great option. They're not too salty or oily, and garnished with just the right amount of manchego. I'm not into the dipping sauce that accompanies them, but that's purely preference, as the peppers are good enough on their own. The mussels are usually excellent, with an ever-changing broth that pairs well with the daily bread varieties that the servers will offer. For $6, you really can't go wrong. Same applies to the happy hour drink specials...I definitely recommend the Eleven Mule!  We've also tried both the tavern menu and dinner menu, but honestly, neither blew me away. The Eleven Burger is highly-rated by so many people, but I honestly didn't like it...at all. The burger, itself (ordered medium), was just chewy and I couldn't taste the meat under the excessive pile of toppings. I could barely get through the bland onion straws that overwhelmed everything...including the blue cheese. Such a disappointment. I'm hoping to try the lamb burger soon, as we often see it pass by, and it looks excellent. Also, as someone from Baltimore, I should've known better than to order the crab cake sandwich. A lot of bread, a tiny amount of crab cake (looked like claw meat, as well). Poor choice on my part, but at a place like Eleven, I really expected a more impressive effort.  The dinner menu is a bit stronger, but it'll hit your wallet pretty hard. Is it worth it? I'm still undecided. I tried the lamb chop (which doesn't seem to be on the current menu). It was good, but dry, which is probably one of the reasons that I haven't been tempted towards the dinner menu again. They did have an excellent tomato salad (also not on the current menu), which is actually what convinced us to stay for dinner in the first place. The atmosphere is definitely fitting if you're looking to impress on a date or business dinner, and the staff is excellent and usually very nice. The menu reads as fine dining, and certainly is priced as such, so come prepared to spend quite a bit. As mentioned before, our verdict is out on whether or not it's worth the cost, but I'm willing to try the full-on dinner experience again at some point. Until then, we'll continue to enjoy the excellent happy hour drinks and bites, nice bar staff, and inviting atmosphere. At a minimum, it's definitely worth stopping in for that.

8Zs5v0m9Ukb2hun-W7Lxww.text: I have always heard great things about Eleven and last night I finally got to experience it first hand. About a month ago I scheduled a dinner party here for my brother's 30th. They were able to accommodate 15 people with no hesitation whatsoever. From the woman I spoke to about booking the reservation, to our servers last night, honestly some of the best customer service I have ever experienced at a restaurant. I had the beef tenderloin and it was one of the best steaks I've had in Pittsburgh. I will definitely be recommending Eleven to all of my friends, and will most definitely be back.

OJ3bRuECUOaxqUnJRcl9DA.text: My boyfriend and I went to Eleven for a fancy date night. Let me preface this review by saying this is NOT a fancy restaurant and you do not need to dress up. I was worried we'd be underdressed, but the waiters wear jeans. I'd say more of a business casual dress code would be appropriate, including dark denim.   Anyways, we got the jumbo crab cake as an appetizer. HOLY CANNOLI BATMAN! It was the most delicious, freshest crab meat I've ever had. There were these fingerling potatoes with them that were so incredible.  My boyfriend got the tenderloin and I got chicken. Our food was exceptional... So amazing. We were both so happy with our meals and would definitely recommend this place to others. The service was great as well... I can't wait to go back.

wfDXydiMF5Cir1WQCx2iAw.text: I came in on a Sunday evening to try the Eleven burger, it didn't disappoint me. The braised veal on top, comboed with the bacon is what really makes this burger stick out. I ordered medium but it was cooked well, I didn't complain because it was still juicy and tasty.  Also, usually after eating huge burgers, I typically feel awful and want to lay in bed until I die, but this burger did not put me into such a death like state, which makes me think that they don't add unnecessary amounts of sodium and their ingredients are high quality.  The service was fine, nothing to complain about, but nothing to brag about. I found no one at the restaurant to be super friendly.  The place is gorgeous, would like to return for something other than a burger.

The total expensive is $100 for two. Considering we have 4 dishes and two deserts, it's not expensive at all. I will definitely go there for the next time.

JlkWkcD7u5kyyzI-i7I49w.text: This place kind of snuck up on me. The tuna tartare was excellent, and the poke was good. All of this was preamble for the lamb. Get the lamb. Do not pass go, do not collection $200. Just get the lamb. Lamb loin cooked, seasoned, and served to perfection accompanied with the decadent, amazing, piece of lamb belly. My party of 8 had a great table that facilitated excellent conversation without being cramped. Solid service and an excellent wine list. Desserts were great. We ordered several and then ordered a 2nd chocolate cake (gluten free!!) because it was just that good. Oh, and get the lamb. Seriously.

dy28-hlMoCSiKMnA2akS5g.text: Eleven out of 10 for me.   Please note that this was a business meal so my cheap a** didn't have to pay for it.   Everything was super fresh and expertly cooked - just the way I asked for.   Started out with raw oysters that were so good, they didn't need any sauce. Very fresh and refreshing.   Then I had the seared salmon which was cooked to perfection. Salmon is a great way to test a restaurants quality standards because if it's not fresh, it will have a fishy smell and taste. This salmon was buttery and delicious.

bMM9ubg7gPQHeaKFfg1VsA.text: My colleague and I ordered the tuna tartare as an appetizer. Light, subtle, yet substantive. The show-stealer for me was my seafood tasting entree, which included the best salmon I've ever had at a restaurant (more rare than medium rare the way I like it), tender bay scallops, and crispy-edged but meaty crab cakes.   I enjoyed my sparkling blueberry mojito and the dessert, peach cannoli. While it was good, probably wasn't the best dessert on the menu.   Definitely a dressy, more formal place with attentive service.

AV6sLyikkHAzTKby31DHbg.text: We absolutely loved Eleven for brunch and dinner was even better! Our waiter Joe was attentive and so knowledgable.  Gerber farms chicken was phenomenal. The risotto phenomenal. Also warm chocolate cake with cheesecake ice cream is a game changer. Other popular items included the beef tenderloin and candy bar dessert. COME HERE.

aga0fyFHCoIMJcQQ8d7i9A.text: Quite possibly my new favorite restaurant in Pittsburgh. Unable to decide on a particular entree, we (party of two) decided to split everything we ordered. For the first course, Jumbo Lump Crab Cake and Berkshire Prosciutto. Main Entree, Beef Tenderloin. Wine, bottle of 2014 Duckhorn Decoy Red Blend Bordeaux. And dessert, Creme Fraiche Brulee. All were otherworldly!!! Also, the ambiance for a party of two is very intimate. We made a 10:30PM reservation and, for the majority of our visit, we were the only two individuals in the dining area of the restaurant. Despite the late arrival, the staff was spectacular and more than accommodating!!  Can't wait to go back and try some of the other menu items!!

-mwCy3PgZOCez_e17fJ3rg.text: Loved this place. Very friendly staff, comfortable seating, quick to get seated and wait staff was very attentive. Cocktails were delicious and the food was incredible. Would highly recommend.

Lm64j2PXK-zaTNdkvpT7wQ.text: I have to ask myself...why did we wait so long to have dinner here? I am not sure. We have been here two times, both for brunch. Both times the food was phenomenal and the service was impeccable. I decided for my birthday dinner that Eleven would be the place to celebrate. We got there a few minutes before our 5 pm reservation. We were greeted warmly and immediately seated. I love the vibe at Eleven. It is chic yet warm and relaxing. We were promptly greeted by our waiter (I am sorry that I cannot remember his name - I am so bad with names - he was fantastic). He was friendly, informative, and knowledgeable about everything on the menu. We ordered apps and drinks to start. I chose the sea scallops which were perfect and paired with a red flannel hash. I had never heard of red flannel hash before and all I have to say about that is...where have you been hiding red flannel hash? Wow...what flavors...beets (never a fan but now I know how good a beet can be), potatoes, amongst other miscellaneous good stuff. Who knew? I got the Sangria as well which is light and was a delight! The hubby got a beer (I cannot remember what he chose but it was terrific). He got the sashimi for his app which was fresh and refreshing. For my entree I chose the pork chop that came with grits. The meat, of course, cooked perfectly. And the grits in stick form and oh so delicious! The hubby got the steak and it came with mashed potatoes. Again the meat was perfect and the potatoes were creamy and amazing as well. Both pieces of meat fresh and tender and juicy. For dessert I got the spice cake in a little bit if apple cider with vanilla ice cream...wow! The hubby got the chocolate cake and ice cream...wow! And to end the meal a Carmel in sea salt that the pastry chef prepared...I just don't have the adjectives to describe how fabulous everything was. From beginning to end it was a truly awesome dining experience. Eleven, never let me down...so yummy!

dDmIWkmfGk4s1lvUL21HGw.text: Our poor server.. we were a group of 10 or 11, and I'll be the firs to admit it- we were obnoxious.  I'm sure within minutes he was annoyed with us, but hey, we were a group of friends celebrating a birthday and enjoying ourselves.  So, on with my review!  We started at the bar where we waited for some of our group to arrive as we were the first there.  The drinks were really great, but our bartenders lacked so much personality that it was sickening.  I dont know why, but we seemed to be an utter annoyance to the guy serving us, and at this point we were just 3 or 4 people sitting at a bar ordering cocktails, so I'm not sure what the attitude was about, but whatever.  We paid our tab and went to our table.  Once we were seated, we had a really good experience for the most part.  Our service was great I thought (bless that poor man! haha!), and I really enjoyed everything I ordered.  The carrott soup was incredible, and my entree was delicious.  In my opinion, considering how loud and difficult I'm sure we were, our server did a great job and I never really felt like he was burdened or impatient with us.  We sat in a semi-private area (thank God) which was really nice, for us and those around us, and it was the perfect setting for our group.    The valet parking situation could be improved, but I dont really have any complaints- it just seems like there may be a more efficient way to do it and the waiting space and valet stand is really cramped and can get uncomfortable if there are a lot of people waiting.  There seems to be plenty of self parking available, but valet is really reasonable and makes it easy.

rI_VTNiDvq6EZzPjf9Kx4A.text: A wonderful restaurant with great ambience. The wait staff was very attentive, service superb. They do not have specials, since the menu changes often. We decided to just order dinner, no appetizers, although the apps sounded very good. We ordered the Swordfish , it was very tasty and fresh, coming with fresh green beans and multicolored peppers. The Seafood Sampler, which was also tasty, however the piece of swordfish was small and only one sea scallop, but a very large crab cake. The crab cake was good, filled with lots of lump crab, just wished  a larger piece of swordfish and maybe 2 scallops, and a smaller crab cake. The vegetable for this dish was "creamed corn", but not the typical creamed corn, it had andouille sausage in it. Also ordered was the Beef Tenderloin, one was ordered medium-perfectly cooked and seasoned appropriately, the other ordered rare and came also perfectly cooked. The potato gnocchi were light and airy, with great flavor, lovely wild mushrooms with the dish. The blue cheese that came with the dish was not subtle. We opted forgoing dessert, since we were full , but the dessert menu looked extremely good.

JSwx_0VfL25rBieHVarpOg.text: This used to be my favorite restaurant in the area. Had dinner there a dozen times and recommended it enthusiastically to everyone. Now I'm sorry I did.   On my last visit to Eleven (and I do mean last) my wife and I thought we had been transported to some other universe. Grumpy parking valet, grim hostess, uncaring waiter who wanted to be somewhere else. All of these things so unlike all of our previous visits.   Maybe I could try to overlook these shortcomings as a bad day or their personal problems. But, when the rack of lamb was served I was sure Rod Serling had to be lurking somewhere in the shadows. The lamb (my very favorite entree) was rubber. Could not be cut with a steak knife.   It was our anniversary and I didn't want to make what my wife would probably define as a scene. Also, I was so flabbergasted by the entire disastrous experience I said nothing. When the waiter took away the uneaten rubber lamb I was sure he would ask why I hadn't finished my tire. But no, nothing.   It's sad since I had enjoyed the place so much in the past. Well, nothing lasts forever.

W6kdwObE760c6C_RQ2iiow.text: Superb cuisine and creativity...and ingredients. Pittsburgh has been starving for this class of restaurant and now it has it. Would hold its own in NY or Chicago or LA!  Wine list needs some help still. $130 for Frog's Leap is shaky on principle alone.

JDdY-1tsuOC77HN7o7Mzfw.text: The place was cozy, staff was very nice, the food was excellent and the price was what you pay for a high quality rendezvous.  People are dressed up, dressed down, dressed casual and it doesn't seem to concern a soul.    I feel as though they could beef up their desserts a little bit better. Perhaps add more selection and more dark chocolate, per my companion.

BYy1Oh6r9uRA33dV5vWrLw.text: I mean really! The beinyet should be illegal. Not a calorie wasted! Great brunch sitting outside on the roof porch. Service on point. Meals delicious. My entire was undercooked and replaced no question asked. Husband ate every bite! No room for dessert but sure would have liked to try!!! Worth the trip. Can't wait to return.

zJPze37UrgeYy4hnemgxtA.text: Upon receipt of the much-coveted Big Burrito birthday voucher this year, I decided to go to Eleven to redeem it.  Two friends accompanied me for my visit on Sun., 12/13, and I was able to given them each a $10 off voucher, so we all were able to receive a discount on an otherwise pricey dinner, which is always nice.  Overall, we were quite impressed with our experience, as the details below will show.  Although we all decided to forego appetizers, we were served bread from a bread basket containing three varieties.  Of the three types we tried, I enjoyed the sea salt focaccia best.  The only thing that's a bit strange is that, instead of placing a basket on the table, they dole it out by the slice, but you can request two slices at a time if you so desire, as I did.  The night of our visit, the entree list was pretty seafood heavy, so all three of us ordered seafood entrees.  My friends ordered the seared salmon and the walleye pike ($28 each), and I ordered the seafood tasting ($36).  The seafood tasting consisted of a crab cake, a sea scallop, and salmon topped with shishito peppers and salt and vinegar chips over some seafood chowder.  The crab cake was generous in size and consisted of lump crab meat with no pepper and very little filler.  It was definitely one of the best crab cakes I've had, which is saying something given that I went to high school and college on the Eastern Shore of MD.  The seared salmon was moist on the inside and crispy on the outside, just as salmon should ideally be.  The sea scallop was also very large and meaty, and tasted appropriately (I must confess I'm not a huge scallop fan).  The chowder and chips made for a nice presentation and accompanied the main components of the dish well.  The only component of the dish that I didn't really care much for were the peppers--but then again, I'm not a big fan of spicy green peppers.  I tried bites of my friends' entrees, and they were both delicious, as well.  After finishing our entrees, we sprung for dessert.  I was torn between the warm dark chocolate cake and the candy bar desserts ($10 each), so when my friends ordered the former, I went for the latter.  I'm really glad I went for the candy bar dessert, since it was absolutely delicious!  It consisted of chocolate olive oil cake, chocolate malt ice cream, and peanut butter sauce, and they even included a piece of white chocolate on which they wrote happy birthday because I mentioned that it was my birthday.  I also tried a bite of my friends' dessert.  While it was delicious, I enjoyed the candy bar dessert more, so I made the right decision.  Needless to say, my friends and I very much enjoyed our dinner at Eleven.  The quality of the ambiance and service matched that of the food, making for a comprehensively wonderful experience.  I've since learned that the head chef will be leaving in a couple of months to start his own restaurant.  I wish him great success in that endeavor, and trust that the new chef, who currently heads Casbah, will be a worthy replacement.  If you're looking for a classy place to dine, I highly recommend Eleven--it easily makes my top 10 restaurant experiences in PGH.

5y4got1BDwMq5zQHK0UpYg.text: This was undoubtedly one of the best happy hour meals I've had.  The BLUE BAY MUSSELS, made with shallots, garlic confit, fennel seed, herbs, sherry, croutons and salami, is a heaping, steaming dish good enough for two people to share. And it's so good.  The PROSCIUTTO TOAST is actually four grilled sourdough toasts topped with smoked ricotta, rhubarb jam and slices of blood orange. These were absolutely amazing. However, I was here three months ago and it looks like the menu's changed a bit. So if you ever see this back on the menu, be sure to get it!

l50XgRtJ0kiBhuyOVv1NAA.text: Enough great things can't be said about this place. Went for a birthday dinner and wasn't disappointed. The scallops app was delicious, the beef tenderloin and snapper entrees were some of the best plates we've ever had. The atmosphere is new and intimate.   Paid parking can be found across the street. Other highlights of the Strip District are a short walk away.

_oSvAgJuKXNj32Q-BsjneQ.text: Stopped here for brunch with my gf before hitting the airport.  DO NOT wear a hoodie or you'll feel like a complete POS.  Didn't even matter that it was from the 412 store, felt super under-dressed the entire time.  Anyways, for food we ordered the smoked salmon app, the linguini, and the fried chicken & biscuits.  The presentation of the smoked salmon app classed-up what is essentially a deconstructed lox bagel, but the taste is otherwise standard.  My gf's linguini with citrus butter, garlic, zucchini, spinach, and crab really just tasted like lemon juice.  Probably avoid that option.  The fried chicken and biscuits was rich and savory.  Absolutely filling, so do not consume if the 'Lers or Pens are playing within the next couple hours.

-FWrpMnbKbA3AMSd_m09YA.text: WOW  this is one of the Best places in Pittsburgh! We went to celebrate our Anniversary and what a great choice it was a very elegant place with very well trained staff. We were seated in this private booth up stairs was so very cool you didn't feel like you were in a big Restaurant and they have a top notch staff. We started off with a glass of Riesling Wine and a Eleven Mule. They have a bread guy that come around with three different types of bread it is warm.  We ordered Smoked Laurel Hill Trout and Cauliflower Soup, Mt husband said it was the best trout he has ever had, the soup was out of this world. For our entree`s we ordered Wild Alaskan Halibut and Beef Tenderloin both were very delicious. For dessert we had Banana Cream Pie and Bourbon Brown Sugar Creme Brulee and espresso both desserts were so very good, the Banana Cream pie was like no other Banana cream that I have ever had. Parking lot across the street from Restaurant for 15.00 or Valet for 6.00 they have a coat check so they were able to take are wet umbrellas for us.

r_6_t6Kf1-7KOaVsvwLAeQ.text: This was the first time my two girlfriends and I stopped in for brunch on a Sunday morning. I noticed the great reviews on Yelp and can say it did not disappoint. We decided on the $30 brunch deal which gives you a cocktail or fresh juice, appetizer, and an entree. Fresh biscuits and jam come to the table as well. We all loved the biscuits! Yum!! I went with the cinnamon roll and eggs Benedict, with a mimosa as my cocktail. Everything was delicious! My favorite was the cinnamon roll because it was probably one of the best ones I have ever had. The eggs Benedict was also yummy. My cocktail tasted like fresh squeezed juice which I loved. Very refreshing. Both of my friends enjoyed their entrees as well and we didn't leave anything on our plates :) Our server was friendly and effiWe can't wait to return when the weather is warmer.   Updated review for dinner: I came here also for my birthday dinner-servers were polite and friendly. Parking can be a bit of a hassle but they do offer valet parking. Food was amazing! Dinner is very pricy if you are willing to spend the money on a fancy night out. Luckily we had a bday coupon. I had the lamb and my boyfriend had the steak! Delicious!

fgPJxrcXdE1RvyqhsxcnvQ.text: I states in my previous review that I wanted to come here for brunch....we did that today and were just as pleased with the service and the food as we were for dinner.   The $29 prix fixe brunch includes an appetizer, entree and alcoholic or other beverage of your choosing. You absolutely cannot beat it. Everything we had was absolutely delicious. We also ordered a side of the beignets to share. Sweet little squares of dough sprinkle with powdered sugar, toasted coconut and a kumquat puree to help cut the sweetness. We also had the oysters, short rib hash, steak and eggs and burger.   The brunch cocktails included in the price are great too. They don't skimp on the alcohol in them, which is the norm for a fixed price menu. At least what we have experienced in the past.   Our server Nicole was fabulous. Very attentive and super sweet. We love Eleven, and have recommended it to many people. Great food, wonderful service and fantastic food. We will be back.

od5c-rhLzg_2YtYz3rX02Q.text: Absolutely loved the salmon salad I had here. My husband had a salad with a chicken breast on top that was huge, the iced tea was very tasty. We had to sit in the bar area because there was no seating left even after 1 o'clock, for lunch. The waitress did a damn good job considering she was serving the entire bar side of the restaurant. Dark lighting in the bathroom. Near the Heinz history center.
